<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">South America</span></h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Continent</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"Southern America" redirects here. For the region of the United States, see <a href="/wiki/Southern_United_States" title="Southern United States">Southern United States</a>. For the botanical continent defined in the World Geographical Scheme for Recording Plant Distributions, see <a href="/wiki/World_Geographical_Scheme_for_Recording_Plant_Distributions#8_Southern_America" title="World Geographical Scheme for Recording Plant Distributions">Southern America (WGSRPD)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1066479718">.mw-parser-output .infobox-subbox{padding:0;border:none;margin:-3px;width:auto;min-width:100%;font-size:100%;clear:none;float:none;background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .infobox-3cols-child{margin:auto}.mw-parser-output .infobox .navbar{font-size:100%}body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-header,body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-subheader,body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-above,body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-title,body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-image,body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-full-data,body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-below{text-align:center}</style><table class="infobox"><caption class="infobox-title">South America</caption><tbody><tr><td class="infobox-image" colspan="2"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:South_America_(orthographic_projection).svg"><img alt="South America (orthographic projection).svg" data-file-height="541" data-file-width="541" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/South_America_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/220px-South_America_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/South_America_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/330px-South_America_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/South_America_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/440px-South_America_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Area</th><td class="infobox-data">17,840,000 km<sup>2</sup> (6,890,000 sq mi) (<a href="/wiki/Continent#Area_and_population" title="Continent">4th</a>)</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Population</th><td class="infobox-data">434,254,119 (2021; <a href="/wiki/List_of_continents_and_continental_subregions_by_population" title="List of continents and continental subregions by population">5th</a>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN_WPP_1-0"><a href="#cite_note-UN_WPP-1">[1]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN_WPP_2022_2-0"><a href="#cite_note-UN_WPP_2022-2">[2]</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Population density</th><td class="infobox-data">21.4/km<sup>2</sup> (56.0/sq mi)</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a> (<a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">PPP</a>)</th><td class="infobox-data"><span class="nowrap">$7.61 trillion (2022 est; <a href="/wiki/List_of_continents_by_GDP#Continents_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of continents by GDP">5th</a>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup></span></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a> (nominal)</th><td class="infobox-data">$3.62 trillion (2022 est; <a href="/wiki/List_of_continents_by_GDP#Continents_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of continents by GDP">4th</a>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">GDP per capita</th><td class="infobox-data">$8,340 (2022 est; <a href="/wiki/List_of_continents_by_GDP#Continents_by_GDP_per_capita_(nominal)" title="List of continents by GDP">5th</a>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-5"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Religions</th><td class="infobox-data"><div class="plainlist"><ul><li><a href="/wiki/Religion_in_South_America#Christianity" title="Religion in South America">Christianity</a> (90.0%)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Survey_6-0"><a href="#cite_note-Survey-6">[6]</a></sup></li><li><a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">No religion</a> (7.7%)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Survey_6-1"><a href="#cite_note-Survey-6">[6]</a></sup></li><li><a href="/wiki/Religion_in_South_America" title="Religion in South America">Other</a> (2.3%)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Survey_6-2"><a href="#cite_note-Survey-6">[6]</a></sup></li></ul></div></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Demonym" title="Demonym">Demonym</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_South_America" title="Demographics of South America">South American</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Countries</th><td class="infobox-data"><div class="mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" style="text-align: center; font-size: 95%;">

</li></ul>

 </li></ul>
</div>

</div></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/UN_M49" title="UN M49">UN M49 code</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><code>005</code> – South America<br/><code>419</code> – <a href="/wiki/Latin_America_and_the_Caribbean" title="Latin America and the Caribbean">Latin America and the Caribbean</a><br/><code>019</code> – <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a><br/><code>001</code> – <a href="/wiki/World" title="World">World</a></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_South_America_(physical,_political,_population)_with_legend.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4134" data-file-width="2880" decoding="async" height="316" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Map_of_South_America_%28physical%2C_political%2C_population%29_with_legend.jpg/220px-Map_of_South_America_%28physical%2C_political%2C_population%29_with_legend.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Map_of_South_America_%28physical%2C_political%2C_population%29_with_legend.jpg/330px-Map_of_South_America_%28physical%2C_political%2C_population%29_with_legend.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Map_of_South_America_%28physical%2C_political%2C_population%29_with_legend.jpg/440px-Map_of_South_America_%28physical%2C_political%2C_population%29_with_legend.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_South_America_(physical,_political,_population)_with_legend.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map of South America showing physical, political, and population characteristics, as per 2018</div></div></div>
<p><b>South America</b> is a <a href="/wiki/Continent" title="Continent">continent</a> entirely in the <a href="/wiki/Western_Hemisphere" title="Western Hemisphere">Western Hemisphere</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12"><a href="#cite_note-12">[note 6]</a></sup> and mostly in the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere" title="Southern Hemisphere">Southern Hemisphere</a>, with a relatively small portion in the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Hemisphere" title="Northern Hemisphere">Northern Hemisphere</a>. It can also be described as the southern <a href="/wiki/Subregion#Americas" title="Subregion">subregion</a> of a single continent called <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">America</a>.
</p><p>South America is bordered on the west by the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Ocean" title="Pacific Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a> and on the north and east by the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a>; <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North America</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_Sea" title="Caribbean Sea">Caribbean Sea</a> lie to the northwest. The continent generally includes twelve sovereign states: <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a>, <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ecuador" title="Ecuador">Ecuador</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guyana" title="Guyana">Guyana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paraguay" title="Paraguay">Paraguay</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru">Peru</a>, <a href="/wiki/Suriname" title="Suriname">Suriname</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uruguay" title="Uruguay">Uruguay</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela">Venezuela</a>; two <a href="/wiki/Dependent_territory" title="Dependent territory">dependent territories</a>: the <a href="/wiki/Falkland_Islands" title="Falkland Islands">Falkland Islands</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_Georgia_and_the_South_Sandwich_Islands" title="South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands">South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13"><a href="#cite_note-13">[note 7]</a></sup> and one <a href="/wiki/Administrative_division" title="Administrative division">internal territory</a>: <a href="/wiki/French_Guiana" title="French Guiana">French Guiana</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14"><a href="#cite_note-14">[note 8]</a></sup> In addition, the <a href="/wiki/ABC_islands_(Leeward_Antilles)" title="ABC islands (Leeward Antilles)">ABC islands</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_the_Netherlands" title="Kingdom of the Netherlands">Kingdom of the Netherlands</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ascension_Island" title="Ascension Island">Ascension Island</a> (dependency of <a href="/wiki/Saint_Helena,_Ascension_and_Tristan_da_Cunha" title="Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha">Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha</a>, a <a href="/wiki/British_Overseas_Territories" title="British Overseas Territories">British Overseas Territory</a>), <a href="/wiki/Bouvet_Island" title="Bouvet Island">Bouvet Island</a> (<a href="/wiki/Dependencies_of_Norway" title="Dependencies of Norway">dependency</a> of <a href="/wiki/Norway" title="Norway">Norway</a>), <a href="/wiki/Panama" title="Panama">Panama</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Trinidad_and_Tobago" title="Trinidad and Tobago">Trinidad and Tobago</a> may also be considered parts of South America.
</p><p>South America has an area of 17,840,000 square kilometers (6,890,000 sq mi). Its population as of 2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=South_America&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> has been estimated at more than 434 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN_WPP_1-1"><a href="#cite_note-UN_WPP-1">[1]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN_WPP_2022_2-1"><a href="#cite_note-UN_WPP_2022-2">[2]</a></sup> South America ranks fourth in area (after <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Africa" title="Africa">Africa</a>, and <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North America</a>) and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_continents_by_population" title="List of continents by population">fifth</a> in population (after Asia, Africa, <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>, and North America). Brazil is by far the most populous South American country, with more than half of the continent's population, followed by Colombia, Argentina, Venezuela and Peru. In recent decades, Brazil has also generated half of the continent's GDP and has become the continent's first regional power.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-academia.edu_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-academia.edu-15">[7]</a></sup>
</p><p>Most of the population lives near the continent's western or eastern coasts while the interior and the <a href="/wiki/Patagonia" title="Patagonia">far south</a> are sparsely populated. The geography of western South America is dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Andes" title="Andes">Andes</a> mountains; in contrast, the eastern part contains both highland regions and vast lowlands where rivers such as the <a href="/wiki/Amazon_River" title="Amazon River">Amazon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Orinoco" title="Orinoco">Orinoco</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paran%C3%A1_River" title="Paraná River">Paraná</a> flow. Most of the continent lies in the <a href="/wiki/Tropics" title="Tropics">tropics</a>, except for a large part of the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Cone" title="Southern Cone">Southern Cone</a> located in the <a href="/wiki/Middle_latitudes" title="Middle latitudes">middle latitudes</a>.
</p><p>The continent's cultural and ethnic outlook has its origin with the interaction of <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas" title="Indigenous peoples of the Americas">indigenous peoples</a> with European <a href="/wiki/Conquistador" title="Conquistador">conquerors</a> and immigrants and, more locally, with <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_slave_trade" title="Atlantic slave trade">African slaves</a>. Given a long <a href="/wiki/European_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="European colonization of the Americas">history of colonialism</a>, the overwhelming majority of South Americans speak <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a> or <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese</a>, and societies and states are rich in <a href="/wiki/Western_culture" title="Western culture">Western traditions</a>. Relative to Europe, Asia and Africa, 20th-century South America has been a peaceful continent with few wars.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16"><a href="#cite_note-16">[8]</a></sup>
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=South_America&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Geography">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_South_America" title="Geography of South America">Geography of South America</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Category:Environment_of_South_America" title="Category:Environment of South America">Category:Environment of South America</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:South_America_-_Blue_Marble_orthographic.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="10000" data-file-width="7200" decoding="async" height="306" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/South_America_-_Blue_Marble_orthographic.jpg/220px-South_America_-_Blue_Marble_orthographic.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/South_America_-_Blue_Marble_orthographic.jpg/330px-South_America_-_Blue_Marble_orthographic.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/South_America_-_Blue_Marble_orthographic.jpg/440px-South_America_-_Blue_Marble_orthographic.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:South_America_-_Blue_Marble_orthographic.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A composite relief image of South America</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_South_America.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="493" decoding="async" height="268" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Map_of_South_America.png/220px-Map_of_South_America.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Map_of_South_America.png/330px-Map_of_South_America.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Map_of_South_America.png/440px-Map_of_South_America.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_South_America.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Modern political map of South America</div></div></div>
<p>South America occupies the southern portion of the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a>. The continent is generally delimited on the northwest by the <a href="/wiki/Dari%C3%A9n_Gap" title="Darién Gap">Darién watershed</a> along the <a href="/wiki/Colombia%E2%80%93Panama_border" title="Colombia–Panama border">Colombia–Panama border</a>, although some may consider the border instead to be the <a href="/wiki/Panama_Canal" title="Panama Canal">Panama Canal</a>. <a href="/wiki/Geopolitics" title="Geopolitics">Geopolitically</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17"><a href="#cite_note-17">[9]</a></sup> and geographically, all of <a href="/wiki/Panama" title="Panama">Panama</a> – including the segment east of the Panama Canal in the isthmus – is typically included in North America alone<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18"><a href="#cite_note-18">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[11]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-North_America_Atlas_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-North_America_Atlas-20">[12]</a></sup> and among the <a href="/wiki/Central_America#Demographics" title="Central America">countries of Central America</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[13]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22"><a href="#cite_note-22">[14]</a></sup> Almost all of mainland South America sits on the <a href="/wiki/South_American_Plate" title="South American Plate">South American Plate</a>.
</p><p>South America is home to the <a href="/wiki/List_of_waterfalls_by_height" title="List of waterfalls by height">world's highest uninterrupted waterfall</a>, <a href="/wiki/Angel_Falls" title="Angel Falls">Angel Falls</a> in Venezuela; the highest single drop waterfall <a href="/wiki/Kaieteur_Falls" title="Kaieteur Falls">Kaieteur Falls</a> in <a href="/wiki/Guyana" title="Guyana">Guyana</a>; the largest river by volume, the <a href="/wiki/Amazon_River" title="Amazon River">Amazon River</a>; the longest mountain range, the <a href="/wiki/Andes" title="Andes">Andes</a> (whose highest mountain is <a href="/wiki/Aconcagua" title="Aconcagua">Aconcagua</a> at 6,962 m or 22,841 ft); the driest non-polar place on earth, the <a href="/wiki/Atacama_Desert" title="Atacama Desert">Atacama Desert</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[15]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[16]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25"><a href="#cite_note-25">[17]</a></sup> the wettest place on earth, <a href="/wiki/L%C3%B3pez_de_Micay" title="López de Micay">López de Micay</a> in Colombia; the largest rainforest, the <a href="/wiki/Amazon_rainforest" title="Amazon rainforest">Amazon rainforest</a>; the highest capital city, <a href="/wiki/La_Paz" title="La Paz">La Paz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a>; the highest commercially navigable lake in the world, <a href="/wiki/Lake_Titicaca" title="Lake Titicaca">Lake Titicaca</a>; and, excluding research stations in <a href="/wiki/Antarctica" title="Antarctica">Antarctica</a>, the world's southernmost permanently inhabited community, <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Toro" title="Puerto Toro">Puerto Toro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a>.
</p><p>South America's major <a href="/wiki/Natural_resource" title="Natural resource">mineral resources</a> are <a href="/wiki/Gold" title="Gold">gold</a>, <a href="/wiki/Silver" title="Silver">silver</a>, <a href="/wiki/Copper" title="Copper">copper</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iron_ore" title="Iron ore">iron ore</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tin" title="Tin">tin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">petroleum</a>. These resources found in South America have brought high income to its countries especially in times of war or of rapid economic growth by industrialized countries elsewhere. However, the concentration in producing one major export <a href="/wiki/Commodity" title="Commodity">commodity</a> often has hindered the development of diversified economies. The fluctuation in the price of commodities in the international markets has led historically to major highs and lows in the economies of South American states, often causing extreme political instability. This is leading to efforts to diversify production to drive away from staying as economies dedicated to one major export.
</p><p>Brazil is the largest country in South America, covering a little less than half of the continent's land area and encompassing around half of the continent's population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26">[18]</a></sup> The remaining countries and territories are divided among four <a href="/wiki/Subregion#South_America" title="Subregion">subregions</a>: the <a href="/wiki/Andean_states" title="Andean states">Andean states</a>, <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_South_America" title="Caribbean South America">Caribbean South America</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Guianas" title="The Guianas">The Guianas</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Cone" title="Southern Cone">Southern Cone</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27"><a href="#cite_note-27">[19]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Outlying_islands">Outlying islands</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=South_America&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Outlying islands">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Nadando_em_Madrisqui_Swimming_at_Madrisqui.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="533" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Nadando_em_Madrisqui_Swimming_at_Madrisqui.jpg/220px-Nadando_em_Madrisqui_Swimming_at_Madrisqui.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Nadando_em_Madrisqui_Swimming_at_Madrisqui.jpg/330px-Nadando_em_Madrisqui_Swimming_at_Madrisqui.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Nadando_em_Madrisqui_Swimming_at_Madrisqui.jpg/440px-Nadando_em_Madrisqui_Swimming_at_Madrisqui.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Nadando_em_Madrisqui_Swimming_at_Madrisqui.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Los_Roques_Archipelago" title="Los Roques Archipelago">Los Roques Archipelago</a>, Venezuela</div></div></div>
<p>Physiographically, South America also includes some of the nearby islands. The <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_the_Netherlands" title="Kingdom of the Netherlands">Dutch</a> <a href="/wiki/ABC_islands_(Leeward_Antilles)" title="ABC islands (Leeward Antilles)">ABC islands</a> (<a href="/wiki/Aruba" title="Aruba">Aruba</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bonaire" title="Bonaire">Bonaire</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cura%C3%A7ao" title="Curaçao">Curaçao</a>), the islands of <a href="/wiki/Trinidad_and_Tobago" title="Trinidad and Tobago">Trinidad and Tobago</a> (<a href="/wiki/Trinidad" title="Trinidad">Trinidad Island</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tobago" title="Tobago">Tobago Island</a> etc.), the <a href="/wiki/Nueva_Esparta" title="Nueva Esparta">State of Nueva Esparta</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Dependencies_of_Venezuela" title="Federal Dependencies of Venezuela">Federal Dependencies of Venezuela</a> sit on the northern portion of the South American <a href="/wiki/Continental_shelf" title="Continental shelf">continental shelf</a> and are sometimes considered parts of the continent. Geopolitically, all the island countries and territories in the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean" title="Caribbean">Caribbean</a> have generally been grouped as a <a href="/wiki/Subregion#North_America" title="Subregion">subregion</a> of North America instead. By contrast, <a href="/wiki/Isla_de_Aves" title="Isla de Aves">Aves Island</a> (administered by <a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela">Venezuela</a>) and the <a href="/wiki/Archipelago_of_San_Andr%C3%A9s,_Providencia_and_Santa_Catalina" title="Archipelago of San Andrés, Providencia and Santa Catalina">Archipelago of San Andrés, Providencia and Santa Catalina</a> (<a href="/wiki/San_Andr%C3%A9s_(island)" title="San Andrés (island)">San Andrés Island</a>, <a href="/wiki/Providencia_Island,_Colombia" title="Providencia Island, Colombia">Providencia Island</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Santa_Catalina_Island_(Colombia)" title="Santa Catalina Island (Colombia)">Santa Catalina Island</a> etc., which are administered by <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a>) are politically parts of South American countries but physiographically parts of North America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-North_America_Atlas_20-1"><a href="#cite_note-North_America_Atlas-20">[12]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[20]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[21]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other islands often associated with geopolitical South America are the <a href="/wiki/Chilo%C3%A9_Archipelago" title="Chiloé Archipelago">Chiloé Archipelago</a> and <a href="/wiki/Robinson_Crusoe_Island" title="Robinson Crusoe Island">Robinson Crusoe Island</a> (both administered by Chile), <a href="/wiki/Easter_Island" title="Easter Island">Easter Island</a> (culturally a part of <a href="/wiki/Oceania" title="Oceania">Oceania</a>, also administered by <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-protectedareas_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-protectedareas-30">[22]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Gal%C3%A1pagos_Islands" title="Galápagos Islands">Galápagos Islands</a> (administered by <a href="/wiki/Ecuador" title="Ecuador">Ecuador</a>, sometimes considered part of Oceania),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-protectedareas_30-1"><a href="#cite_note-protectedareas-30">[22]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[23]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[24]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Tierra_del_Fuego" title="Tierra del Fuego">Tierra del Fuego</a> (split between Argentina and Chile). In the Atlantic Ocean, <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a> administers <a href="/wiki/Fernando_de_Noronha" title="Fernando de Noronha">Fernando de Noronha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Trindade_and_Martim_Vaz" title="Trindade and Martim Vaz">Trindade and Martim Vaz</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter_and_Saint_Paul_Archipelago" title="Saint Peter and Saint Paul Archipelago">Saint Peter and Saint Paul Archipelago</a>, while the <a href="/wiki/Falkland_Islands" title="Falkland Islands">Falkland Islands</a> (<a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a>: <i lang="es">Islas Malvinas</i>) and <a href="/wiki/South_Georgia_and_the_South_Sandwich_Islands" title="South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands">South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands</a> (<a href="/wiki/Antarctic_realm" title="Antarctic realm">biographically</a> and <a href="/wiki/Antarctic_Convergence" title="Antarctic Convergence">hydrologically</a> associated with Antarctica)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[25]</a></sup> have been administered as two <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Overseas_Territory" title="British Overseas Territory">British Overseas Territories</a> under <a href="/wiki/The_Crown" title="The Crown">the Crown</a>, whose sovereignty over the islands is <a href="/wiki/Falkland_Islands_sovereignty_dispute" title="Falkland Islands sovereignty dispute">disputed</a> by <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a>.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Special_cases">Special cases</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=South_America&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Special cases">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>An isolated <a href="/wiki/High_island" title="High island">volcanic island</a> on the <a href="/wiki/South_American_Plate" title="South American Plate">South American Plate</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ascension_Island" title="Ascension Island">Ascension Island</a> is geologically a part of South America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[26]</a></sup> Administered as a dependency of <a href="/wiki/Saint_Helena,_Ascension_and_Tristan_da_Cunha" title="Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha">Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha</a>, the island is geopolitically <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_geoscheme_for_Africa#Western_Africa" title="United Nations geoscheme for Africa">a part</a> of <a href="/wiki/Africa" title="Africa">Africa</a>.
</p><p>An uninhabited <a href="/wiki/Subantarctic" title="Subantarctic">sub-Antarctic</a> volcanic island located in the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">South Atlantic Ocean</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bouvet_Island" title="Bouvet Island">Bouvet Island</a> (administered by <a href="/wiki/Norway" title="Norway">Norway</a>) is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Antarctic_and_Subantarctic_islands#List_of_Antarctic_islands_north_of_60°_S" title="List of Antarctic and Subantarctic islands">geographically</a>, <a href="/wiki/Antarctic_Plate" title="Antarctic Plate">geologically</a>, <a href="/wiki/Antarctic_realm" title="Antarctic realm">biographically</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Antarctic_Convergence" title="Antarctic Convergence">hydrologically</a> associated with <a href="/wiki/Antarctica" title="Antarctica">Antarctica</a>, but the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_geoscheme_for_the_Americas#South_America" title="United Nations geoscheme for the Americas">United Nations geoscheme</a> has included the territory in South America instead.
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=South_America&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Climate">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:442px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_South_America_present.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="850" data-file-width="1294" decoding="async" height="289" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Koppen-Geiger_Map_South_America_present.svg/440px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_South_America_present.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Koppen-Geiger_Map_South_America_present.svg/660px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_South_America_present.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Koppen-Geiger_Map_South_America_present.svg/880px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_South_America_present.svg.png 2x" width="440"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_South_America_present.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen-Geiger climate classification</a> map for South America<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[27]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:372px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tropical_cyclones_1945_2006_wikicolor.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1358" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="251" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Tropical_cyclones_1945_2006_wikicolor.png/370px-Tropical_cyclones_1945_2006_wikicolor.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Tropical_cyclones_1945_2006_wikicolor.png/555px-Tropical_cyclones_1945_2006_wikicolor.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Tropical_cyclones_1945_2006_wikicolor.png/740px-Tropical_cyclones_1945_2006_wikicolor.png 2x" width="370"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tropical_cyclones_1945_2006_wikicolor.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map of all tropical cyclone tracks from 1945 to 2006</div></div></div>
<p>The distribution of the average temperatures in the region presents a constant regularity from the <a href="/wiki/30th_parallel_south" title="30th parallel south">30° of latitude south</a>, when the isotherms tend, more and more, to be confused with the degrees of latitude.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Climate_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-Climate-36">[28]</a></sup>
</p><p>In temperate latitudes, <a href="/wiki/Winter" title="Winter">winters</a> and <a href="/wiki/Summer" title="Summer">summers</a> are milder than in North America. This is because the most extensive part of the continent is in the equatorial zone (the region has more areas of equatorial plains than any other region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Climate_36-1"><a href="#cite_note-Climate-36">[28]</a></sup>), therefore giving the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Cone" title="Southern Cone">Southern Cone</a> more oceanic influence, which moderates year round temperatures.
</p><p>The average annual temperatures in the Amazon basin oscillate around 27 °C (81 °F), with low thermal amplitudes and high <a href="/wiki/Rain" title="Rain">rainfall</a> indices. Between the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maracaibo_Lake" title="Maracaibo Lake">Maracaibo Lake</a> and the mouth of the Orinoco, predominates an <a href="/wiki/Tropical_rainforest_climate" title="Tropical rainforest climate">equatorial climate</a> of the type Congolese, that also includes parts of the Brazilian territory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Climate_36-2"><a href="#cite_note-Climate-36">[28]</a></sup>
</p><p>The east-central Brazilian plateau has a humid and warm tropical climate. The northern and eastern parts of the Argentine pampas have a <a href="/wiki/Subtropics" title="Subtropics">humid subtropical climate</a> with dry winters and humid summers of the Chinese type, while the western and eastern ranges have a subtropical climate of the dinaric type. At the highest points of the Andean region, climates are colder than the ones occurring at the highest point of the Norwegian fjords. In the Andean plateaus, the warm climate prevails, although it is tempered by the altitude, while in the coastal strip, there is an equatorial climate of the Guinean type. From this point until the north of the Chilean coast appear, successively, <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_climate" title="Mediterranean climate">Mediterranean oceanic climate</a>, temperate of the Breton type and, already in <a href="/wiki/Tierra_del_Fuego" title="Tierra del Fuego">Tierra del Fuego</a>, cold climate of the Siberian type.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Climate_36-3"><a href="#cite_note-Climate-36">[28]</a></sup>
</p><p>The distribution of rainfall is related to the regime of winds and air masses. In most of the <a href="/wiki/Tropics" title="Tropics">tropical region</a> east of the Andes, winds blowing from the northeast, east and southeast carry moisture from the Atlantic, causing abundant rainfall. However, due to a consistently strong <a href="/wiki/Wind_shear" title="Wind shear">wind shear</a> and a weak <a href="/wiki/Intertropical_Convergence_Zone" title="Intertropical Convergence Zone">Intertropical Convergence Zone</a>, <a href="/wiki/South_Atlantic_tropical_cyclone" title="South Atlantic tropical cyclone">South Atlantic tropical cyclones</a> are rare.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[29]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/Llanos" title="Llanos">Orinoco Llanos</a> and in the <a href="/wiki/The_Guianas" title="The Guianas">Guianas Plateau</a>, the precipitation levels go from moderate to high. The Pacific coast of Colombia and northern Ecuador are rainy regions, with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/El_Choc%C3%B3" title="El Chocó">Chocó</a> in Colombia being the rainiest place in the world along with the northern slopes of Indian Himalayas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[30]</a></sup> The Atacama Desert, along this stretch of coast, is one of the driest regions in the world. The central and southern parts of Chile are subject to <a href="/wiki/Extratropical_cyclone" title="Extratropical cyclone">extratropical cyclones</a>, and most of the Argentine <a href="/wiki/Patagonia" title="Patagonia">Patagonia</a> is <a href="/wiki/Desert" title="Desert">desert</a>. In the <a href="/wiki/Pampas" title="Pampas">Pampas</a> of Argentina, Uruguay and South of Brazil the rainfall is moderate, with rains well distributed during the year. The moderately dry conditions of the Chaco oppose the intense rainfall of the eastern region of Paraguay. In the <a href="/wiki/Semi-arid_climate" title="Semi-arid climate">semiarid</a> coast of the Brazilian Northeast the rains are linked to a monsoon regime.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Climate_36-4"><a href="#cite_note-Climate-36">[28]</a></sup>
</p><p>Important factors in the determination of climates are sea currents, such as the current Humboldt and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Falklands" title="Falklands">Falklands</a>. The equatorial current of the South Atlantic strikes the coast of the Northeast and there is divided into two others: the current of Brazil and a coastal current that flows to the northwest towards the <a href="/wiki/Antilles" title="Antilles">Antilles</a>, where there it moves towards northeast course thus forming the most Important and famous ocean current in the world, the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_Stream" title="Gulf Stream">Gulf Stream</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Climate_36-5"><a href="#cite_note-Climate-36">[28]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Know.net_39-0"><a href="#cite_note-Know.net-39">[31]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fauna">Fauna</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=South_America&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Fauna">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Fauna_of_South_America" title="Fauna of South America">Fauna of South America</a></div>
<p>South America is one of the most biodiverse continents on Earth. South America is home to many unique species of animals including the <a href="/wiki/Llama" title="Llama">llama</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anaconda" title="Anaconda">anaconda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Piranha" title="Piranha">piranha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jaguar" title="Jaguar">jaguar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vicu%C3%B1a" title="Vicuña">vicuña</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tapir" title="Tapir">tapir</a>. The Amazon rainforests possess high <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity" title="Biodiversity">biodiversity</a>, containing a major proportion of Earth's <a href="/wiki/Species" title="Species">species</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=South_America&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_South_America" title="History of South America">History of South America</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory">Prehistory</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=South_America&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Prehistory">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/History_of_South_America#Pre-Columbian_era" title="History of South America">History of South America § Pre-Columbian era</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:SantaCruz-CuevaManos-P2210651b.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/SantaCruz-CuevaManos-P2210651b.jpg/220px-SantaCruz-CuevaManos-P2210651b.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/SantaCruz-CuevaManos-P2210651b.jpg/330px-SantaCruz-CuevaManos-P2210651b.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/SantaCruz-CuevaManos-P2210651b.jpg/440px-SantaCruz-CuevaManos-P2210651b.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:SantaCruz-CuevaManos-P2210651b.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The prehistoric <a href="/wiki/Cueva_de_las_Manos" title="Cueva de las Manos">Cueva de las Manos</a>, or "Cave of the Hands", in Argentina</div></div></div>
<p>South America is thought to have been first inhabited by humans when people were crossing the <a href="/wiki/Beringia" title="Beringia">Bering Land Bridge</a> (now the <a href="/wiki/Bering_Strait" title="Bering Strait">Bering Strait</a>) at least 15,000 years ago from the territory that is present-day Russia. They migrated south through North America, and eventually reached South America through the <a href="/wiki/Isthmus_of_Panama" title="Isthmus of Panama">Isthmus of Panama</a>.
</p><p>The first evidence for the existence of the human race in South America dates back to about 9000 BC, when <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Squash_(plant)" title="Squash (plant)">squashes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chili_pepper" title="Chili pepper">chili peppers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bean" title="Bean">beans</a> began to be cultivated for food in the highlands of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Amazon_Basin" title="Amazon Basin">Amazon Basin</a>. Pottery evidence further suggests that <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manioc" title="Manioc">manioc</a>, which remains a <a href="/wiki/Staple_food" title="Staple food">staple food</a> today, was being cultivated as early as 2000 BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OBrienP-Oxford_Atlas_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-OBrienP-Oxford_Atlas-40">[32]</a></sup>
</p><p>By 2000 BC, many <a href="/wiki/Agrarian_society" title="Agrarian society">agrarian</a> communities had been settled throughout the <a href="/wiki/Andes" title="Andes">Andes</a> and the surrounding regions. Fishing became a widespread practice along the coast, helping establish fish as a primary source of food. Irrigation systems were also developed at this time, which aided in the rise of an <a href="/wiki/Agrarian_society" title="Agrarian society">agrarian society</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OBrienP-Oxford_Atlas_40-1"><a href="#cite_note-OBrienP-Oxford_Atlas-40">[32]</a></sup>
</p><p>South American cultures began domesticating <a href="/wiki/Llama" title="Llama">llamas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vicu%C3%B1a" title="Vicuña">vicuñas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guanaco" title="Guanaco">guanacos</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Alpaca" title="Alpaca">alpacas</a> in the highlands of the Andes circa 3500 BC. Besides their use as sources of meat and wool, these animals were used for transportation of goods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OBrienP-Oxford_Atlas_40-2"><a href="#cite_note-OBrienP-Oxford_Atlas-40">[32]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pre-Columbian_civilizations">Pre-Columbian civilizations</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=South_America&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Pre-Columbian civilizations">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Pre-Columbian_era#South_America" title="Pre-Columbian era">Pre-Columbian era § South America</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Machu_Picchu,_Per%C3%BA,_2015-07-30,_DD_39.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5496" data-file-width="6399" decoding="async" height="189" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Machu_Picchu%2C_Per%C3%BA%2C_2015-07-30%2C_DD_39.JPG/220px-Machu_Picchu%2C_Per%C3%BA%2C_2015-07-30%2C_DD_39.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Machu_Picchu%2C_Per%C3%BA%2C_2015-07-30%2C_DD_39.JPG/330px-Machu_Picchu%2C_Per%C3%BA%2C_2015-07-30%2C_DD_39.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Machu_Picchu%2C_Per%C3%BA%2C_2015-07-30%2C_DD_39.JPG/440px-Machu_Picchu%2C_Per%C3%BA%2C_2015-07-30%2C_DD_39.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Machu_Picchu,_Per%C3%BA,_2015-07-30,_DD_39.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Inca estate of <a href="/wiki/Machu_Picchu" title="Machu Picchu">Machu Picchu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru">Peru</a> is one of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_Seven_Wonders_of_the_World#Winners" title="New Seven Wonders of the World">New Seven Wonders of the World</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The rise of plant growing and the subsequent appearance of permanent human settlements allowed for the multiple and overlapping beginnings of civilizations in South America.
</p><p>One of the earliest known South American civilizations was at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norte_Chico_civilization" title="Norte Chico civilization">Norte Chico</a>, on the central <a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru">Peruvian</a> coast. Though a pre-ceramic culture, the monumental architecture of Norte Chico is contemporaneous with the pyramids of <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">Ancient Egypt</a>. Norte Chico governing class established a trade network and developed agriculture then followed by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chavin_culture" title="Chavin culture">Chavín</a> by 900 BC, according to some estimates and archaeological finds. Artifacts were found at a site called <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chav%C3%ADn_de_Huantar" title="Chavín de Huantar">Chavín de Huantar</a> in modern Peru at an elevation of 3,177 meters (10,423 ft). Chavín civilization spanned 900 BC to 300 BC.
</p><p>In the central coast of Peru, around the beginning of the 1st millennium AD, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Moche_(culture)" title="Moche (culture)">Moche</a> (100 BC – 700 AD, at the northern coast of Peru), <a href="/wiki/Paracas_culture" title="Paracas culture">Paracas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nazca_culture" title="Nazca culture">Nazca</a> (400 BC – 800 AD, Peru) cultures flourished with centralized states with permanent militia improving agriculture through <a href="/wiki/Irrigation" title="Irrigation">irrigation</a> and new styles of ceramic art. At the <a href="/wiki/Altiplano" title="Altiplano">Altiplano</a>, Tiahuanaco or <a href="/wiki/Tiwanaku" title="Tiwanaku">Tiwanaku</a> (100 BC – 1200 AD, Bolivia) managed a large commercial network based on religion.
</p><p>Around the 7th century, both Tiahuanaco and Wari or <a href="/wiki/Wari_culture" title="Wari culture">Huari</a> Empire (600–1200, Central and northern Peru) expanded its influence to all the Andean region, imposing the Huari urbanism and Tiahuanaco religious iconography.
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muisca_people" title="Muisca people">Muisca</a> were the main indigenous civilization in what is now Colombia. They established the <a href="/wiki/Muisca_Confederation" title="Muisca Confederation">Muisca Confederation</a> of many clans, or <i><a href="/wiki/Cacique" title="Cacique">cacicazgos</a></i>, that had a free trade network among themselves. They were goldsmiths and farmers.
</p><p>Other important Pre-Columbian cultures include: the <a href="/wiki/Ca%C3%B1ari" title="Cañari">Cañaris</a> (in south central Ecuador), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chim%C3%BA_Empire" title="Chimú Empire">Chimú Empire</a> (1300–1470, Peruvian northern coast), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chachapoyas_culture" title="Chachapoyas culture">Chachapoyas</a>, and the Aymaran kingdoms (1000–1450, Western Bolivia and southern Peru).
Holding their capital at the great city of <a href="/wiki/Cusco" title="Cusco">Cusco</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Inca_civilization" title="Inca civilization">Inca civilization</a> dominated the Andes region from 1438 to 1533. Known as <i>Tawantin suyu</i>, and "the land of the four regions," in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Quechua_languages" title="Quechua languages">Quechua</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Inca_Empire" title="Inca Empire">Inca Empire</a> was highly distinct and developed. Inca rule extended to nearly a hundred linguistic or ethnic communities, some nine to fourteen million people connected by a 25,000 kilometer <a href="/wiki/Inca_road_system" title="Inca road system">road system</a>. Cities were built with precise, unmatched stonework, constructed over many levels of mountain terrain. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Terrace_farming" title="Terrace farming">Terrace farming</a> was a useful form of agriculture.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Mapuche" title="Mapuche">Mapuche</a> in Central and Southern Chile resisted the European and Chilean settlers, waging the <a href="/wiki/Arauco_War" title="Arauco War">Arauco War</a> for more than 300 years.
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="European_colonization">European colonization</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=South_America&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: European colonization">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Spanish_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="Spanish colonization of the Americas">Spanish colonization of the Americas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="Portuguese colonization of the Americas">Portuguese colonization of the Americas</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vespucci%27s_first_voyage,_from_Letter_to_Soderini.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="550" data-file-width="529" decoding="async" height="177" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Vespucci%27s_first_voyage%2C_from_Letter_to_Soderini.jpg/170px-Vespucci%27s_first_voyage%2C_from_Letter_to_Soderini.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Vespucci%27s_first_voyage%2C_from_Letter_to_Soderini.jpg/255px-Vespucci%27s_first_voyage%2C_from_Letter_to_Soderini.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Vespucci%27s_first_voyage%2C_from_Letter_to_Soderini.jpg/340px-Vespucci%27s_first_voyage%2C_from_Letter_to_Soderini.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vespucci%27s_first_voyage,_from_Letter_to_Soderini.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Woodcut depicting Italian explorer <a href="/wiki/Amerigo_Vespucci" title="Amerigo Vespucci">Amerigo Vespucci</a>'s first voyage (1497–98) to the New World, from the first known published edition of Vespucci's 1504 letter to <a href="/wiki/Piero_Soderini" title="Piero Soderini">Piero Soderini</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>In 1494, <a href="/wiki/Portugal" title="Portugal">Portugal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a>, the two great maritime European powers of that time, on the expectation of new lands being discovered in the west, signed the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Tordesillas" title="Treaty of Tordesillas">Treaty of Tordesillas</a>, by which they agreed, with the support of the Pope, that all the land outside Europe should be an exclusive <a href="/wiki/Duopoly" title="Duopoly">duopoly</a> between the two countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[33]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Inca-Spanish_confrontation.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="900" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Inca-Spanish_confrontation.JPG/220px-Inca-Spanish_confrontation.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Inca-Spanish_confrontation.JPG/330px-Inca-Spanish_confrontation.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Inca-Spanish_confrontation.JPG/440px-Inca-Spanish_confrontation.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Inca-Spanish_confrontation.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Spanish_conquest_of_the_Inca_Empire" title="Spanish conquest of the Inca Empire">Inca–Spanish confrontation</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Cajamarca" title="Battle of Cajamarca">Battle of Cajamarca</a> left thousands of natives dead.</div></div></div>
<p>The treaty established an imaginary line along a north–south <a href="/wiki/Meridian_(geography)" title="Meridian (geography)">meridian</a> 370 <a href="/wiki/League_(unit)" title="League (unit)">leagues</a> west of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cape_Verde_Islands" title="Cape Verde Islands">Cape Verde Islands</a>, roughly 46° 37' W. In terms of the treaty, all land to the west of the line (known to comprise most of the South American soil) would belong to Spain, and all land to the east, to Portugal. As accurate measurements of <a href="/wiki/Longitude" title="Longitude">longitude</a> were impossible at that time, the line was not strictly enforced, resulting in a <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="Portuguese colonization of the Americas">Portuguese expansion of Brazil</a> across the meridian.
</p><p>Beginning in the 1530s, the people and natural resources of South America were repeatedly exploited by foreign <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Conquistadors" title="Conquistadors">conquistadors</a>, first from Spain and later from Portugal. These competing colonial nations claimed the land and resources as their own and divided it into colonies.
</p><p>European infectious diseases (<a href="/wiki/Smallpox" title="Smallpox">smallpox</a>, <a href="/wiki/Influenza" title="Influenza">influenza</a>, <a href="/wiki/Measles" title="Measles">measles</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Typhus" title="Typhus">typhus</a>) – to which the <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas" title="Indigenous peoples of the Americas">native populations</a> had no immune resistance – caused large-scale depopulation of the native population under Spanish control. Systems of forced labor, such as the <a href="/wiki/Hacienda" title="Hacienda">haciendas</a> and mining industry's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mita_(Inca)" title="Mita (Inca)">mit'a</a> also contributed to the depopulation. After this, <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_slave_trade" title="Atlantic slave trade">enslaved Africans</a>, who had developed immunities to these diseases, were quickly brought in to replace them.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Desembarque_de_Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral_em_Porto_Seguro_em_1500_by_Oscar_Pereira_da_Silva_(1865%E2%80%931939).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2775" data-file-width="4288" decoding="async" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Desembarque_de_Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral_em_Porto_Seguro_em_1500_by_Oscar_Pereira_da_Silva_%281865%E2%80%931939%29.jpg/220px-Desembarque_de_Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral_em_Porto_Seguro_em_1500_by_Oscar_Pereira_da_Silva_%281865%E2%80%931939%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Desembarque_de_Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral_em_Porto_Seguro_em_1500_by_Oscar_Pereira_da_Silva_%281865%E2%80%931939%29.jpg/330px-Desembarque_de_Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral_em_Porto_Seguro_em_1500_by_Oscar_Pereira_da_Silva_%281865%E2%80%931939%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Desembarque_de_Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral_em_Porto_Seguro_em_1500_by_Oscar_Pereira_da_Silva_%281865%E2%80%931939%29.jpg/440px-Desembarque_de_Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral_em_Porto_Seguro_em_1500_by_Oscar_Pereira_da_Silva_%281865%E2%80%931939%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Desembarque_de_Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral_em_Porto_Seguro_em_1500_by_Oscar_Pereira_da_Silva_(1865%E2%80%931939).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Portuguese explorer <a href="/wiki/Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral" title="Pedro Álvares Cabral">Pedro Álvares Cabral</a> landing in Brazil in 1500</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Waterkant_seen_from_Suriname_river_III.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2448" data-file-width="3264" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Waterkant_seen_from_Suriname_river_III.JPG/220px-Waterkant_seen_from_Suriname_river_III.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Waterkant_seen_from_Suriname_river_III.JPG/330px-Waterkant_seen_from_Suriname_river_III.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Waterkant_seen_from_Suriname_river_III.JPG/440px-Waterkant_seen_from_Suriname_river_III.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Waterkant_seen_from_Suriname_river_III.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dutch_colonial_empire" title="Dutch colonial empire">Dutch</a> <a href="/wiki/Colonial_architecture" title="Colonial architecture">colonial houses</a> in <a href="/wiki/Paramaribo" title="Paramaribo">Paramaribo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Suriname" title="Suriname">Suriname</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Frans_Post_-_Paisagem_de_Pernambuco.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1072" data-file-width="1478" decoding="async" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Frans_Post_-_Paisagem_de_Pernambuco.jpg/220px-Frans_Post_-_Paisagem_de_Pernambuco.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Frans_Post_-_Paisagem_de_Pernambuco.jpg/330px-Frans_Post_-_Paisagem_de_Pernambuco.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Frans_Post_-_Paisagem_de_Pernambuco.jpg/440px-Frans_Post_-_Paisagem_de_Pernambuco.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Frans_Post_-_Paisagem_de_Pernambuco.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A painting of the settlement of <a href="/wiki/Pernambuco" title="Pernambuco">Pernambuco</a> in colonial Brazil by <a href="/wiki/Frans_Post" title="Frans Post">Frans Post</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Imperios_Espa%C3%B1ol_y_Portugu%C3%A9s_1790.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="2655" decoding="async" height="249" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Imperios_Espa%C3%B1ol_y_Portugu%C3%A9s_1790.svg/220px-Imperios_Espa%C3%B1ol_y_Portugu%C3%A9s_1790.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Imperios_Espa%C3%B1ol_y_Portugu%C3%A9s_1790.svg/330px-Imperios_Espa%C3%B1ol_y_Portugu%C3%A9s_1790.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Imperios_Espa%C3%B1ol_y_Portugu%C3%A9s_1790.svg/440px-Imperios_Espa%C3%B1ol_y_Portugu%C3%A9s_1790.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Imperios_Espa%C3%B1ol_y_Portugu%C3%A9s_1790.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A map of the Spanish and Portuguese colonies in the Americas in 1790</div></div></div>
<p>The Spaniards were committed to converting their native subjects to <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> and were quick to purge any native cultural practices that hindered this end; however, many initial attempts at this were only partially successful, as native groups simply blended <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholicism</a> with their established beliefs and practices. Furthermore, the Spaniards brought their language to the degree they did with their religion, although the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Church" title="Roman Catholic Church">Roman Catholic Church</a>'s evangelization in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Quechua_language" title="Quechua language">Quechua</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aymara_language" title="Aymara language">Aymara</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Guaran%C3%AD_language" title="Guaraní language">Guaraní</a> actually contributed to the continuous use of these native languages albeit only in the oral form.
</p><p>Eventually, the <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas" title="Indigenous peoples of the Americas">natives</a> and the Spaniards interbred, forming a <a href="/wiki/Mestizo" title="Mestizo">mestizo</a> class. At the beginning, many mestizos of the Andean region were offspring of Amerindian mothers and Spanish fathers. After independence, most mestizos had native fathers and European or mestizo mothers.
</p><p>Many native artworks were considered pagan idols and destroyed by Spanish explorers; this included many gold and silver sculptures and other artifacts found in South America, which were melted down before their transport to Spain or Portugal. Spaniards and Portuguese brought the western European architectural style to the continent, and helped to improve infrastructures like bridges, roads, and the sewer system of the cities they discovered or conquered. They also significantly increased economic and trade relations, not just between the old and new world but between the different South American regions and peoples. Finally, with the expansion of the Portuguese and Spanish languages, many cultures that were previously separated became united through that of Latin American.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Guyana" title="Guyana">Guyana</a> was initially <a href="/wiki/Dutch_colonisation_of_the_Guianas" title="Dutch colonisation of the Guianas">colonized by the Dutch</a> before coming under <a href="/wiki/British_Guiana" title="British Guiana">British control</a>, though there was a brief period during the <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a> when it was occupied by the <a href="/wiki/First_French_Empire" title="First French Empire">French</a>. The region was initially partitioned between the Dutch, French and British before fully coming under the control of Britain.
</p><p>Suriname was first explored by the Spanish in the 16th century and then <a href="/wiki/Surinam_(English_colony)" title="Surinam (English colony)">settled by the English</a> in the mid-17th century. It became a <a href="/wiki/Surinam_(Dutch_colony)" title="Surinam (Dutch colony)">Dutch colony</a> in 1667. 
<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[34]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Slavery_in_South_America">Slavery in South America</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=South_America&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Slavery in South America">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1045330069">.mw-parser-output .sidebar{width:22em;float:right;clear:right;margin:0.5em 0 1em 1em;background:#f8f9fa;border:1px solid <div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="background:transparent;border-top:1px solid #aaa;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/History_of_slavery" title="History of slavery">Historical</a></div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content">
<dl><dt><a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_antiquity" title="Slavery in antiquity">Antiquity</a></dt></dl>

<li><a href="/wiki/Kholop" title="Kholop">Kholop</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Serfdom" title="Serfdom">Serfs</a>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/History_of_serfdom" title="History of serfdom">History</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Serfdom_in_Russia" title="Serfdom in Russia">In Russia</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Emancipation_reform_of_1861" title="Emancipation reform of 1861">Emancipation</a></li></ul></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Thrall" title="Thrall">Thrall</a></li></ul>
