contains <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research" title="Wikipedia:No original research">original research</a></b>. Table seem to be original research (OR). Section seem plagued by OR and inconsistencies.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=South_America&amp;action=edit">improve it</a> by <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">verifying</a> the claims made and adding <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources#Inline_citations" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">inline citations</a>. Statements consisting only of original research should be removed.</span> <span class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">May 2020</span>)</i></span><span class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<small><a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a></small>)</i></span></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_South_America" title="Ethnic groups in South America">Ethnic groups in South America</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Venezuelan_protest_Madrid_2019.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1306" data-file-width="1850" decoding="async" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Venezuelan_protest_Madrid_2019.jpg/220px-Venezuelan_protest_Madrid_2019.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Venezuelan_protest_Madrid_2019.jpg/330px-Venezuelan_protest_Madrid_2019.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Venezuelan_protest_Madrid_2019.jpg/440px-Venezuelan_protest_Madrid_2019.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Venezuelan_protest_Madrid_2019.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Spanish_immigration_to_Venezuela" title="Spanish immigration to Venezuela">Spanish-Venezuelan</a> protesters in Madrid.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Japanese_Brazilian_Miko_Curitiba_Paran%C3%A1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="761" data-file-width="615" decoding="async" height="210" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Japanese_Brazilian_Miko_Curitiba_Paran%C3%A1.jpg/170px-Japanese_Brazilian_Miko_Curitiba_Paran%C3%A1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Japanese_Brazilian_Miko_Curitiba_Paran%C3%A1.jpg/255px-Japanese_Brazilian_Miko_Curitiba_Paran%C3%A1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Japanese_Brazilian_Miko_Curitiba_Paran%C3%A1.jpg/340px-Japanese_Brazilian_Miko_Curitiba_Paran%C3%A1.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Japanese_Brazilian_Miko_Curitiba_Paran%C3%A1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A Japanese-Brazilian <a href="/wiki/Miko" title="Miko">Miko</a> during a festival in <a href="/wiki/Curitiba" title="Curitiba">Curitiba</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Festuva.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="399" data-file-width="600" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Festuva.jpg/220px-Festuva.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Festuva.jpg/330px-Festuva.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Festuva.jpg/440px-Festuva.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Festuva.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Former president of Brazil Lula and members of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italian_Brazilian" title="Italian Brazilian">Italian Brazilian</a> community during the Grape Festival at <a href="/wiki/Caxias_do_Sul" title="Caxias do Sul">Caxias do Sul</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Quechuawomanandchild.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3072" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Quechuawomanandchild.jpg/220px-Quechuawomanandchild.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Quechuawomanandchild.jpg/330px-Quechuawomanandchild.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Quechuawomanandchild.jpg/440px-Quechuawomanandchild.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Quechuawomanandchild.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Peruvian" title="Peruvian">Peruvian</a> woman and her son</div></div></div>
<p>Genetic admixture occurs at very high levels in South America. In Argentina, the European influence accounts for 65–79% of the genetic background, Amerindian for 17–31% and sub-Saharan African for 2–4%. In Colombia, the sub-Saharan African genetic background varied from 1% to 89%, while the European genetic background varied from 20% to 79%, depending on the region.
In Peru, European ancestries ranged from 1% to 31%, while the African contribution was only 1% to 3%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[70]</a></sup> The Genographic Project determined the average Peruvian from Lima had about 28% European ancestry, 68% Native American, 2% Asian ancestry and 2% sub-Saharan African.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[71]</a></sup>
</p><p>Descendants of <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_South_America" title="Indigenous peoples of South America">indigenous peoples</a>, such as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Quechuas" title="Quechuas">Quechua</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aymara_people" title="Aymara people">Aymara</a>, or the <a href="/wiki/Urarina" title="Urarina">Urarina</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[72]</a></sup> of Amazonia make up the majority of the population in Bolivia (56%) and Peru (44%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[73]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[74]</a></sup> In Ecuador, Amerindians are a large minority that comprises two-fifths of the population. The native European population is also a significant element in most other former Portuguese colonies.
</p><p>People who identify as of primarily or totally <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Light_skinned_people" title="Light skinned people">European descent</a>, or identify their <a href="/wiki/Phenotype" title="Phenotype">phenotype</a> as corresponding to such group, are a majority in Argentina,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[75]</a></sup> Uruguay<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-blanca_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-blanca-88">[76]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Chile" title="Demographics of Chile">Chile</a> (64.7%),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[77]</a></sup> and are 48.4% of the population in Brazil.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[78]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[79]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[80]</a></sup> In Venezuela, according to the national census, 42% of the population is primarily native Spanish, Italian and Portuguese descendants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[81]</a></sup> In Colombia, people who identify as European descendants are about 37%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Society_and_Its_Environment_94-0"><a href="#cite_note-The_Society_and_Its_Environment-94">[82]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-schwartzman_95-0"><a href="#cite_note-schwartzman-95">[83]</a></sup> In Peru, European descendants are the third group in number (15%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[84]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Mestizo" title="Mestizo">Mestizos</a> (mixed European and Amerindian) are the largest ethnic group in Bolivia, Paraguay, Venezuela, Colombia<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Society_and_Its_Environment_94-1"><a href="#cite_note-The_Society_and_Its_Environment-94">[82]</a></sup> and Ecuador and the second group in Peru and Chile.
</p><p>South America is also home to one of the largest populations of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_of_Africa" title="Ethnic groups of Africa">Africans</a>. This group is significantly present in Brazil, Colombia, <a href="/wiki/Guyana" title="Guyana">Guyana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Suriname" title="Suriname">Suriname</a>, French Guiana, Venezuela and Ecuador.
</p><p>Brazil followed by Peru have the largest <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japanese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Korea" title="Korea">Korean</a> and <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">Chinese</a> communities in South America, Lima has the largest ethnic Chinese community in Latin America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[85]</a></sup> Guyana and Suriname have the largest ethnic <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">East Indian</a> community.
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>

<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Indigenous_people">Indigenous people</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=South_America&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Indigenous people">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Indigenous_peoples_of_South_America" title="List of Indigenous peoples of South America">List of Indigenous peoples of South America</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_South_America" title="Indigenous peoples in South America">Indigenous peoples in South America</a></div>
<p>In many places indigenous people still practice a traditional lifestyle based on subsistence agriculture or as hunter-gatherers. There are still some <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Uncontacted_people" title="Uncontacted people">uncontacted tribes</a> residing in the Amazon Rainforest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[89]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r998391716">.mw-parser-output .div-col{margin-top:0.3em;column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .div-col-small{font-size:90%}.mw-parser-output .div-col-rules{column-rule:1px solid #aaa}.mw-parser-output .div-col dl,.mw-parser-output .div-col ol,.mw-parser-output .div-col ul{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .div-col li,.mw-parser-output .div-col dd{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}</style><div class="div-col">
<ul><li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aguarunas" title="Aguarunas">Aguarunas</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alacalufe" title="Alacalufe">Alacalufe</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arawaks" title="Arawaks">Arawaks</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ashanincas" title="Ashanincas">Ashanincas</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atacame%C3%B1os" title="Atacameños">Atacameños</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aw%C3%A1-Guaj%C3%A1_people" title="Awá-Guajá people">Awá</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Aymara_people" title="Aymara people">Aymara</a> – live in the <a href="/wiki/Altiplano" title="Altiplano">Altiplano</a> of <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a> and <a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru">Peru</a>. Their language is co-official in <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru">Peru</a>. Traditional lifestyle includes llama herding.</li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Banaw%C3%A1_people" title="Banawá people">Banawa</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ca%C3%B1ari" title="Cañari">Cañaris</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caiapos" title="Caiapos">Caiapos</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chibcha" title="Chibcha">Chibcha</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Cocama_language" title="Cocama language">Cocama</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chayahuita" title="Chayahuita">Chayahuita</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Diaguita" title="Diaguita">Diaguita</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Enxet" title="Enxet">Enxet</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ge_(people)" title="Ge (people)">Gê</a>,</li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Guarani_people" title="Guarani people">Guaraní</a> – live in Paraguay where the <a href="/wiki/Guarani_language" title="Guarani language">Guarani language</a> is co-official with Spanish. The ethnic group is also found in Bolivia.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Juris" title="Juris">Juris</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kuna_(people)" title="Kuna (people)">Kuna</a> live on the <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a>–<a href="/wiki/Panama" title="Panama">Panama</a> border.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Mapuche" title="Mapuche">Mapuche</a> – live mainly in southern Chile and southwestern Argentina (see <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Araucanian" title="Araucanian">Araucanian</a>).</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Mats%C3%A9s" title="Matsés">Matsés</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Pehuenche" title="Pehuenche">Pehuenche</a> – a branch of Mapuches that lived in the Andean valleys of southern (see <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Araucanian" title="Araucanian">Araucanian</a>).</li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Quechuas" title="Quechuas">Quechuas</a> – make up a large part of the population of Peru and Bolivia. Are diverse as an ethnic group. The Incas spoke <a href="/wiki/Southern_Quechua" title="Southern Quechua">Southern Quechua</a>.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Selk%27nam_people" title="Selk'nam people">Selknam</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shipibo" title="Shipibo">Shipibo</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shuar_people" title="Shuar people">Shuar</a> (see <a href="/wiki/Jivaroan_peoples" title="Jivaroan peoples">Jívaro</a>).</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tupi_people" title="Tupi people">Tupi</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Urarina" title="Urarina">Urarina</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wai-Wai_people" title="Wai-Wai people">Wai-Wai</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wayuu" title="Wayuu">Wayuu</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Xukuru_people" title="Xukuru people">Xucuru</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yaghan_people" title="Yaghan people">Yaghan</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yagua_people" title="Yagua people">Yagua</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Y%C4%85nomam%C3%B6" title="Yąnomamö">Yąnomamö</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zaparos" title="Zaparos">Zaparos</a></li></ul>
</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Populace">Populace</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=South_America&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Populace">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader" style="text-align:center;background-color:">South American cities</div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="São Paulo">São Paulo</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires" title="Buenos Aires">Buenos Aires</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Urca,_Rio_de_Janeiro_-_State_of_Rio_de_Janeiro,_Brazil_-_panoramio_(14).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="677" data-file-width="1052" decoding="async" height="129" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Urca%2C_Rio_de_Janeiro_-_State_of_Rio_de_Janeiro%2C_Brazil_-_panoramio_%2814%29.jpg/300px-Urca%2C_Rio_de_Janeiro_-_State_of_Rio_de_Janeiro%2C_Brazil_-_panoramio_%2814%29.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Santiago_de_Chile_(winter).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="637" data-file-width="1279" decoding="async" height="100" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Santiago_de_Chile_%28winter%29.jpg/200px-Santiago_de_Chile_%28winter%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Santiago_de_Chile_%28winter%29.jpg/300px-Santiago_de_Chile_%28winter%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Santiago_de_Chile_%28winter%29.jpg/400px-Santiago_de_Chile_%28winter%29.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Santiago" title="Santiago">Santiago</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The most populous country in South America is Brazil with 214.3 million people. The second largest country is Colombia with a population of 51,516,562. Argentina is the third most populous country with 45,276,780.
</p><p>While Brazil, Argentina, and Colombia maintain the largest populations, large city populations are not restricted to those nations. The largest cities in South America, by far, are <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="São Paulo">São Paulo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires" title="Buenos Aires">Buenos Aires</a>, <a href="/wiki/Santiago" title="Santiago">Santiago</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lima" title="Lima">Lima</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bogot%C3%A1" title="Bogotá">Bogotá</a>. These cities are the only cities on the continent whose metropolitan areas' population exceed eight million. Next in size are <a href="/wiki/Caracas" title="Caracas">Caracas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Belo_Horizonte" title="Belo Horizonte">Belo Horizonte</a>, <a href="/wiki/Medell%C3%ADn" title="Medellín">Medellin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/San_Salvador" title="San Salvador">San Salvador</a>.
</p><p>Five of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_in_the_Americas" title="List of metropolitan areas in the Americas">top ten metropolitan areas</a> are in Brazil. These metropolitan areas all have a population of above 4 million and include the <a href="/wiki/Greater_S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="Greater São Paulo">São Paulo metropolitan area</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greater_Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Greater Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro metropolitan area</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Greater_Belo_Horizonte" title="Greater Belo Horizonte">Belo Horizonte metropolitan area</a>. Whilst the majority of the largest metropolitan areas are within Brazil, Argentina is host to the second largest metropolitan area by population in South America: the <a href="/wiki/Greater_Buenos_Aires" title="Greater Buenos Aires">Buenos Aires metropolitan region</a> is above 13 million inhabitants.
</p><p>South America has also been witness to the growth of <a href="/wiki/Megalopolis" title="Megalopolis">megapolitan areas</a>. In Brazil four megaregions exist including the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Expanded_Metropolitan_Complex_of_S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="Expanded Metropolitan Complex of São Paulo">Expanded Metropolitan Complex of São Paulo</a> with more than 32 million inhabitants. The others are the Greater Rio, Greater Belo Horizonte and <a href="/wiki/Greater_Porto_Alegre" title="Greater Porto Alegre">Greater Porto Alegre</a>. Colombia also has four megaregions which comprise 72% of its population, followed by Venezuela, Argentina and Peru which are also homes of megaregions.
</p><p>The top ten largest South American metropolitan areas by population as of 2015, based on national census numbers from each country:
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=South_America&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Economy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_South_America" title="Economy of South America">Economy of South America</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Latin_American_and_Caribbean_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of Latin American and Caribbean countries by GDP (nominal)">List of Latin American and Caribbean countries by GDP (nominal)</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_South_American_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of South American countries by GDP (PPP)">List of South American countries by GDP (PPP)</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1097763485" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><table class="box-Update plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Update" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div class="mbox-image-div"><img alt="Ambox current red Americas.svg" data-file-height="290" data-file-width="360" decoding="async" height="34" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg/42px-Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg/63px-Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg/84px-Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg.png 2x" width="42"/></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This section needs to be <b>updated</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help update this article to reflect recent events or newly available information.</span> <span class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">March 2017</span>)</i></span></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sao_Paulo_Stock_Exchange.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1918" data-file-width="3612" decoding="async" height="117" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Sao_Paulo_Stock_Exchange.jpg/220px-Sao_Paulo_Stock_Exchange.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Sao_Paulo_Stock_Exchange.jpg/330px-Sao_Paulo_Stock_Exchange.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Sao_Paulo_Stock_Exchange.jpg/440px-Sao_Paulo_Stock_Exchange.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sao_Paulo_Stock_Exchange.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Trading panel of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BM%26F_Bovespa" title="BM&amp;F Bovespa">São Paulo Stock Exchange</a> is the second biggest in the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a> and 13th in the world.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:CostaneraCenter2016.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3844" data-file-width="5184" decoding="async" height="163" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/CostaneraCenter2016.jpg/220px-CostaneraCenter2016.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/CostaneraCenter2016.jpg/330px-CostaneraCenter2016.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/CostaneraCenter2016.jpg/440px-CostaneraCenter2016.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:CostaneraCenter2016.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Financial center of <a href="/wiki/Santiago" title="Santiago">Santiago</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a></div></div></div></div></div>

<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Petrobrasbolivia2006.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1772" data-file-width="2553" decoding="async" height="153" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Petrobrasbolivia2006.jpg/220px-Petrobrasbolivia2006.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Petrobrasbolivia2006.jpg/330px-Petrobrasbolivia2006.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Petrobrasbolivia2006.jpg/440px-Petrobrasbolivia2006.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Petrobrasbolivia2006.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Refinery" title="Refinery">Refinery</a> of Brazilian state-owned <a href="/wiki/Petrobras" title="Petrobras">Petrobras</a> in <a href="/wiki/Cochabamba" title="Cochabamba">Cochabamba</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chuqui001_02.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1040" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Chuqui001_02.jpg/220px-Chuqui001_02.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Chuqui001_02.jpg/330px-Chuqui001_02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Chuqui001_02.jpg/440px-Chuqui001_02.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Chuqui001_02.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Chuquicamata" title="Chuquicamata">Chuquicamata</a> is the largest <a href="/wiki/Open-pit_mining" title="Open-pit mining">open pit mine</a> in the world, near the city of <a href="/wiki/Calama,_Chile" title="Calama, Chile">Calama</a> in Chile.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Apresenta%C3%A7%C3%A3o_KC-390_(15414135738).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1136" data-file-width="1800" decoding="async" height="139" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Apresenta%C3%A7%C3%A3o_KC-390_%2815414135738%29.jpg/220px-Apresenta%C3%A7%C3%A3o_KC-390_%2815414135738%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Apresenta%C3%A7%C3%A3o_KC-390_%2815414135738%29.jpg/330px-Apresenta%C3%A7%C3%A3o_KC-390_%2815414135738%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Apresenta%C3%A7%C3%A3o_KC-390_%2815414135738%29.jpg/440px-Apresenta%C3%A7%C3%A3o_KC-390_%2815414135738%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Apresenta%C3%A7%C3%A3o_KC-390_(15414135738).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Embraer_KC-390" title="Embraer KC-390">KC-390</a> is the largest military transport aircraft produced in South America by the Brazilian company <a href="/wiki/Embraer" title="Embraer">Embraer</a>.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bodega_chakana_hacia_la_monta%C3%B1a.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4108" data-file-width="3504" decoding="async" height="199" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Bodega_chakana_hacia_la_monta%C3%B1a.jpg/170px-Bodega_chakana_hacia_la_monta%C3%B1a.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Bodega_chakana_hacia_la_monta%C3%B1a.jpg/255px-Bodega_chakana_hacia_la_monta%C3%B1a.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Bodega_chakana_hacia_la_monta%C3%B1a.jpg/340px-Bodega_chakana_hacia_la_monta%C3%B1a.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bodega_chakana_hacia_la_monta%C3%B1a.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Vineyard" title="Vineyard">Vineyard</a> in <a href="/wiki/Luj%C3%A1n_de_Cuyo" title="Luján de Cuyo">Luján de Cuyo</a>, province of <a href="/wiki/Mendoza,_Argentina" title="Mendoza, Argentina">Mendoza, Argentina</a></div></div></div>
<p>South America relies less on the export of both manufactured goods and natural resources than the world average; merchandise exports from the continent were 16% of GDP on an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nominal_GDP" title="Nominal GDP">exchange rate</a> basis, compared to 25% for the world as a whole.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wfex_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-wfex-102">[90]</a></sup> Brazil (the seventh largest economy in the world and the largest in South America) leads <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_exports" title="List of countries by exports">in terms of merchandise exports</a> at $251 billion, followed by Venezuela at $93 billion, Chile at $86 billion, and Argentina at $84 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wfex_102-1"><a href="#cite_note-wfex-102">[90]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since 1930, the continent has experienced remarkable growth and diversification in most economic sectors. Most agricultural and livestock products are destined for the domestic market and local consumption. However, the export of <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">agricultural products</a> is essential for the <a href="/wiki/Balance_of_trade" title="Balance of trade">balance of trade</a> in most countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Economy_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-Economy-103">[91]</a></sup>
</p><p>The main agrarian crops are export crops, such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soy" title="Soy">soy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wheat" title="Wheat">wheat</a>. The production of staple foods such as vegetables, corn or beans is large, but focused on domestic consumption. Livestock raising for meat exports is important in Argentina, Paraguay, Uruguay and Colombia. In tropical regions the most important crops are <a href="/wiki/Coffee" title="Coffee">coffee</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cocoa_bean" title="Cocoa bean">cocoa</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bananas" title="Bananas">bananas</a>, mainly in Brazil, Colombia and Ecuador. Traditionally, the countries producing <a href="/wiki/Sugar" title="Sugar">sugar</a> for export are Peru, Guyana and Suriname, and in Brazil, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sugar_cane" title="Sugar cane">sugar cane</a> is also used to make <a href="/wiki/Ethanol" title="Ethanol">ethanol</a>. On the coast of Peru, northeast and south of Brazil, <a href="/wiki/Cotton" title="Cotton">cotton</a> is grown. 50.5% of the South America's land surface is covered by forest,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[92]</a></sup> but timber industries are small and directed to domestic markets. In recent years, however, transnational companies have been settling in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Amazon_forest" title="Amazon forest">Amazon</a> to exploit noble timber destined for export. The Pacific coastal waters of South America are the most important for commercial fishing. The anchovy catch reaches thousands of tonnes, and tuna is also abundant (Peru is a major exporter). The capture of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Crustaceans" title="Crustaceans">crustaceans</a> is remarkable, particularly in northeastern Brazil and Chile.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Economy_103-1"><a href="#cite_note-Economy-103">[91]</a></sup>
</p><p>Only Brazil and Argentina are part of the <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a> (industrial countries), while only Brazil is part of the <a href="/wiki/G8%2B5" title="G8+5">G8+5</a> (the most powerful and influential nations in the world). In the tourism sector, a series of negotiations began in 2005 to promote tourism and increase air connections within the region. <a href="/wiki/Punta_del_Este" title="Punta del Este">Punta del Este</a>, <a href="/wiki/Florian%C3%B3polis" title="Florianópolis">Florianópolis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mar_del_Plata" title="Mar del Plata">Mar del Plata</a> are among the most important resorts in South America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Economy_103-2"><a href="#cite_note-Economy-103">[91]</a></sup>
</p><p>The most industrialized countries in South America are Brazil, Argentina, Chile, Colombia, Venezuela and Uruguay respectively. These countries alone account for more than 75 percent of the region's economy and add up to a GDP of more than US$3.0 trillion. Industries in South America began to take on the economies of the region from the 1930s when the <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression" title="Great Depression">Great Depression</a> in the United States and other countries of the world boosted industrial production in the continent. From that period the region left the agricultural side behind and began to achieve high rates of economic growth that remained until the early 1990s when they slowed due to political instabilities, economic crises and neoliberal policies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Economy_103-3"><a href="#cite_note-Economy-103">[91]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since the end of the economic crisis in Brazil and Argentina that occurred in the period from 1998 to 2002, which has led to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Economic_recession" title="Economic recession">economic recession</a>, rising unemployment and falling population income, the industrial and service sectors have been recovering rapidly. Chile, Argentina and Brazil have recovered fastest, growing at an average of 5% per year. All of South America after this period has been recovering and showing good signs of economic stability, with controlled <a href="/wiki/Inflation" title="Inflation">inflation</a> and exchange rates, continuous growth, a decrease in <a href="/wiki/Social_inequality" title="Social inequality">social inequality</a> and unemployment–factors that favor industry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Economy_103-4"><a href="#cite_note-Economy-103">[91]</a></sup>
</p><p>The main industries are: electronics, textiles, food, automotive, metallurgy, aviation, naval, clothing, beverage, steel, tobacco, timber, chemical, among others. Exports reach almost US$400 billion annually, with Brazil accounting for half of this.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Economy_103-5"><a href="#cite_note-Economy-103">[91]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Economic_inequality" title="Economic inequality">economic gap</a> between the rich and poor in most South American nations is larger than on most other continents. The richest 10% receive over 40% of the nation's income in Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, and Paraguay,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-share_105-0"><a href="#cite_note-share-105">[93]</a></sup> while the poorest 20% receive 4% or less in Bolivia, Brazil, and Colombia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[94]</a></sup> This wide gap can be seen in many large South American cities where makeshift shacks and slums lie in the vicinity of skyscrapers and upper-class luxury apartments; nearly one in nine South Americans live on less than $2 per day (on a <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a> basis).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wb2_107-0"><a href="#cite_note-wb2-107">[95]</a></sup>
</p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Economically_largest_cities_as_of_2014">Economically largest cities as of 2014</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=South_America&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Economically largest cities as of 2014">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>

<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Faz_S_Sofia_canavial_090607_REFON.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2176" data-file-width="3264" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Faz_S_Sofia_canavial_090607_REFON.JPG/220px-Faz_S_Sofia_canavial_090607_REFON.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Faz_S_Sofia_canavial_090607_REFON.JPG/330px-Faz_S_Sofia_canavial_090607_REFON.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Faz_S_Sofia_canavial_090607_REFON.JPG/440px-Faz_S_Sofia_canavial_090607_REFON.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Faz_S_Sofia_canavial_090607_REFON.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Sugarcane plantation in <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_(state)" title="São Paulo (state)">São Paulo</a>. In 2018, Brazil was the world's largest producer, with 746 million tonnes. South America produces half of the world's sugarcane.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:SojaBrasnorte.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3280" data-file-width="4928" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/SojaBrasnorte.jpg/220px-SojaBrasnorte.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/SojaBrasnorte.jpg/330px-SojaBrasnorte.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/SojaBrasnorte.jpg/440px-SojaBrasnorte.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:SojaBrasnorte.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Soy plantation in <a href="/wiki/Mato_Grosso" title="Mato Grosso">Mato Grosso</a>. In 2020, Brazil was the world's largest producer, with 130 million tonnes. South America produces half of the world's soybeans.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Coffee_Plantation.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="762" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="84" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Coffee_Plantation.jpg/220px-Coffee_Plantation.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Coffee_Plantation.jpg/330px-Coffee_Plantation.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Coffee_Plantation.jpg/440px-Coffee_Plantation.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Coffee_Plantation.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Coffee in <a href="/wiki/Minas_Gerais" title="Minas Gerais">Minas Gerais</a>. In 2018, Brazil was the world's largest producer, with 3.5 million tonnes. South America produces half of the world's coffee.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Laranja_(Avar%C3%A9)_REFON_1.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1979" data-file-width="2992" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Laranja_%28Avar%C3%A9%29_REFON_1.JPG/220px-Laranja_%28Avar%C3%A9%29_REFON_1.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Laranja_%28Avar%C3%A9%29_REFON_1.JPG/330px-Laranja_%28Avar%C3%A9%29_REFON_1.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Laranja_%28Avar%C3%A9%29_REFON_1.JPG/440px-Laranja_%28Avar%C3%A9%29_REFON_1.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Laranja_(Avar%C3%A9)_REFON_1.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Orange in <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_(state)" title="São Paulo (state)">São Paulo</a>. In 2018, Brazil was the world's largest producer, with 17 million tonnes. South America produces 25% of the world's orange.</div></div></div>
<p>The four countries with the strongest agriculture are <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a> and <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a>. Currently:
</p>
<ul><li>Brazil is the world's largest producer of <a href="/wiki/Sugarcane" title="Sugarcane">sugarcane</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soy" title="Soy">soy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coffee" title="Coffee">coffee</a>, <a href="/wiki/Orange_(fruit)" title="Orange (fruit)">orange</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Guaran%C3%A1" title="Guaraná">guaraná</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/A%C3%A7a%C3%AD" title="Açaí">açaí</a> and <a href="/wiki/Brazil_nut" title="Brazil nut">Brazil nut</a>; is one of the top 5 producers of <a href="/wiki/Maize" title="Maize">maize</a>, <a href="/wiki/Papaya" title="Papaya">papaya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tobacco" title="Tobacco">tobacco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pineapple" title="Pineapple">pineapple</a>, <a href="/wiki/Banana" title="Banana">banana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cotton" title="Cotton">cotton</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beans" title="Beans">beans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coconut" title="Coconut">coconut</a>, <a href="/wiki/Watermelon" title="Watermelon">watermelon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lemon" title="Lemon">lemon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yerba_mate" title="Yerba mate">yerba mate</a>; is one of the top 10 world producers of <a href="/wiki/Cocoa_bean" title="Cocoa bean">cocoa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cashew" title="Cashew">cashew</a>, <a href="/wiki/Avocado" title="Avocado">avocado</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tangerine" title="Tangerine">tangerine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Persimmon" title="Persimmon">persimmon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mango" title="Mango">mango</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guava" title="Guava">guava</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">rice</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oat" title="Oat">oat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sorghum" title="Sorghum">sorghum</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tomato" title="Tomato">tomato</a>; and is one of the top 15 world producers of <a href="/wiki/Grape" title="Grape">grape</a>, <a href="/wiki/Apple" title="Apple">apple</a>, <a href="/wiki/Melon" title="Melon">melon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peanut" title="Peanut">peanut</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Common_fig" title="Common fig">fig</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peach" title="Peach">peach</a>, <a href="/wiki/Onion" title="Onion">onion</a>, <a href="/wiki/Palm_oil" title="Palm oil">palm oil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Natural_rubber" title="Natural rubber">natural rubber</a>;</li>
<li>Argentina is the world's largest producer of <a href="/wiki/Yerba_mate" title="Yerba mate">yerba mate</a>; is one of the 5 largest producers in the world of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soy" title="Soy">soy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maize" title="Maize">maize</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sunflower_seed" title="Sunflower seed">sunflower seed</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lemon" title="Lemon">lemon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pear" title="Pear">pear</a>, one of the 10 largest producers in the world of <a href="/wiki/Barley" title="Barley">barley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Grape" title="Grape">grape</a>, <a href="/wiki/Artichoke" title="Artichoke">artichoke</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tobacco" title="Tobacco">tobacco</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cotton" title="Cotton">cotton</a>, and one of the 15 largest producers in the world of <a href="/wiki/Wheat" title="Wheat">wheat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oat" title="Oat">oat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chickpea" title="Chickpea">chickpea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sugarcane" title="Sugarcane">sugarcane</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sorghum" title="Sorghum">sorghum</a> and <a href="/wiki/Grapefruit" title="Grapefruit">grapefruit</a>;</li>
<li>Chile is one of the 5 largest world producers of <a href="/wiki/Cherry" title="Cherry">cherry</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cranberry" title="Cranberry">cranberry</a>, and one of the 10 largest world producers of <a href="/wiki/Grape" title="Grape">grape</a>, <a href="/wiki/Apple" title="Apple">apple</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kiwifruit" title="Kiwifruit">kiwi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peach" title="Peach">peach</a>, <a href="/wiki/Plum" title="Plum">plum</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hazelnut" title="Hazelnut">hazelnut</a>, focusing on exporting high-value fruits;</li>
<li>Colombia is one of the 5 largest producers in the world of <a href="/wiki/Coffee" title="Coffee">coffee</a>, <a href="/wiki/Avocado" title="Avocado">avocado</a> and <a href="/wiki/Palm_oil" title="Palm oil">palm oil</a>, and one of the 10 largest producers in the world of <a href="/wiki/Sugarcane" title="Sugarcane">sugarcane</a>, <a href="/wiki/Banana" title="Banana">banana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pineapple" title="Pineapple">pineapple</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cocoa_bean" title="Cocoa bean">cocoa</a>;</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru">Peru</a> is the world's largest producer of <a href="/wiki/Quinoa" title="Quinoa">quinoa</a>; is one of the 5 largest producers of <a href="/wiki/Avocado" title="Avocado">avocado</a>, <a href="/wiki/Blueberry" title="Blueberry">blueberry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Artichoke" title="Artichoke">artichoke</a> and <a href="/wiki/Asparagus" title="Asparagus">asparagus</a>; one of the 10 largest producers in the world of <a href="/wiki/Coffee" title="Coffee">coffee</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cocoa_bean" title="Cocoa bean">cocoa</a>; one of the 15 largest producers in the world of <a href="/wiki/Potato" title="Potato">potato</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pineapple" title="Pineapple">pineapple</a>, and also has a considerable production of <a href="/wiki/Grape" title="Grape">grape</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sugarcane" title="Sugarcane">sugarcane</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">rice</a>, <a href="/wiki/Banana" title="Banana">banana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maize" title="Maize">maize</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cassava" title="Cassava">cassava</a>; its agriculture is considerably diversified;</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Paraguay" title="Paraguay">Paraguay</a>'s agriculture is currently developing, being currently the 6th largest producer of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soy" title="Soy">soy</a> in the world and entering the list of the 20 largest producers of <a href="/wiki/Maize" title="Maize">maize</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sugarcane" title="Sugarcane">sugarcane</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[101]</a></sup></li></ul>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Perdigao.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Perdigao.jpg/220px-Perdigao.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Perdigao.jpg/330px-Perdigao.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Perdigao.jpg/440px-Perdigao.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Perdigao.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Truck of a meat company in Brazil. South America produces 20% of the world's beef and chicken meat.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a> is the world's largest exporter of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chicken_meat" title="Chicken meat">chicken meat</a>: 3.77 million tonnes in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[102]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[103]</a></sup> The country is the holder of the second largest herd of cattle in the world, 22.2% of the world herd. The country was the second largest producer of beef in 2019, responsible for 15.4% of global production.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[104]</a></sup> It was also the 3rd largest world producer of milk in 2018. This year, the country produced 35.1 billion liters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[105]</a></sup> In 2019, Brazil was the 4th largest pork producer in the world, with almost 4 million tonnes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[106]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2018, <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a> was the 4th largest producer of <a href="/wiki/Beef" title="Beef">beef</a> in the world, with a production of 3 million tonnes (behind only USA, Brazil and China). <a href="/wiki/Uruguay" title="Uruguay">Uruguay</a> is also a major meat producer. In 2018, it produced 589 thousand tonnes of beef.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[107]</a></sup>
</p><p>In <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chicken_meat" title="Chicken meat">chicken meat</a> production, Argentina ranks among the 15 largest producers in the world, and Peru and Colombia among the 20 biggest producers. In <a href="/wiki/Beef" title="Beef">beef</a> production, Colombia is one of the 20 largest producers in the world. In <a href="/wiki/Honey" title="Honey">honey</a> production, Argentina ranks among the 5 largest producers in the world, and Brazil among the 15 largest. In terms of production of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cow%27s_milk" title="Cow's milk">cow's milk</a>, Argentina ranks among the 20 largest producers in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[108]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:EMS_-_panoramio.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="664" data-file-width="1293" decoding="async" height="113" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/EMS_-_panoramio.jpg/220px-EMS_-_panoramio.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/EMS_-_panoramio.jpg/330px-EMS_-_panoramio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/EMS_-_panoramio.jpg/440px-EMS_-_panoramio.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:EMS_-_panoramio.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/EMS_(pharmaceuticals)" title="EMS (pharmaceuticals)">EMS</a>, the largest Brazilian pharmaceutical industry</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Planta_Braskem.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="472" data-file-width="713" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Planta_Braskem.jpg/220px-Planta_Braskem.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Planta_Braskem.jpg/330px-Planta_Braskem.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Planta_Braskem.jpg/440px-Planta_Braskem.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Planta_Braskem.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Braskem" title="Braskem">Braskem</a>, the largest Brazilian chemical industry</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a> annually lists the top manufacturing countries by total manufacturing value. According to the 2019 list, <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a> has the thirteenth most valuable industry in the world (US$173.6 billion), <a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela">Venezuela</a> the thirtieth largest (US$58.2 billion, however, it depends on oil to obtain this value), <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a> the 31st largest (US$57.7 billion), <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a> the 46th largest (US$35.4 billion), <a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru">Peru</a> the 50th largest (US$28.7 billion) and <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a> the 51st largest (US$28.3 billion).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[109]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a> has the third-largest manufacturing sector in the Americas. Accounting for 28.5 percent of GDP, Brazil's industries range from automobiles, steel, and petrochemicals to computers, <a href="/wiki/Aircraft" title="Aircraft">aircraft</a> (<a href="/wiki/Embraer" title="Embraer">Embraer</a>), food, pharmaceutical, footwear, metallurgy and consumer durables. In the <a href="/wiki/Food_industry" title="Food industry">food industry</a>, in 2019, Brazil was the second largest exporter of processed foods in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[110]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[111]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[112]</a></sup> In 2016, the country was the 2nd largest producer of <a href="/wiki/Pulp_(paper)" title="Pulp (paper)">pulp</a> in the world and the 8th producer of <a href="/wiki/Paper" title="Paper">paper</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[113]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[114]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[115]</a></sup> In the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Footwear_industry" title="Footwear industry">footwear industry</a>, in 2019, Brazil ranked 4th among world producers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[116]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[117]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[118]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[119]</a></sup> In 2019, the country was the 8th producer of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vehicles" title="Vehicles">vehicles</a> and the 9th producer of <a href="/wiki/Steel" title="Steel">steel</a> in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[120]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[121]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[122]</a></sup> In 2018, the <a href="/wiki/Chemical_industry" title="Chemical industry">chemical industry</a> of Brazil was the 8th in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[123]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[124]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[125]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Textile_industry" title="Textile industry">textile industry</a>, Brazil, although it was among the 5 largest world producers in 2013, is very little integrated in world trade.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[126]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cerro_ricco.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1800" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Cerro_ricco.jpg/220px-Cerro_ricco.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Cerro_ricco.jpg/330px-Cerro_ricco.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Cerro_ricco.jpg/440px-Cerro_ricco.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cerro_ricco.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Cerro_Rico" title="Cerro Rico">Cerro Rico</a>, <a href="/wiki/Potos%C3%AD_Department" title="Potosí Department">Potosi</a>, Bolivia, still a major silver mine</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Brasil_-_Ametista_do_Sul_-_Piedra_amatista.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3968" data-file-width="2976" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Brasil_-_Ametista_do_Sul_-_Piedra_amatista.jpg/170px-Brasil_-_Ametista_do_Sul_-_Piedra_amatista.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Brasil_-_Ametista_do_Sul_-_Piedra_amatista.jpg/255px-Brasil_-_Ametista_do_Sul_-_Piedra_amatista.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Brasil_-_Ametista_do_Sul_-_Piedra_amatista.jpg/340px-Brasil_-_Ametista_do_Sul_-_Piedra_amatista.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Brasil_-_Ametista_do_Sul_-_Piedra_amatista.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Amethyst mine in <a href="/wiki/Ametista_do_Sul" title="Ametista do Sul">Ametista do Sul</a>. South America is a major producer of gems such as amethyst, topaz, emerald, aquamarine and tourmaline</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Itabira_MG_Brasil_-_Mina_de_Ferro_da_Vale_-_panoramio.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2472" data-file-width="3296" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Itabira_MG_Brasil_-_Mina_de_Ferro_da_Vale_-_panoramio.jpg/220px-Itabira_MG_Brasil_-_Mina_de_Ferro_da_Vale_-_panoramio.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Itabira_MG_Brasil_-_Mina_de_Ferro_da_Vale_-_panoramio.jpg/330px-Itabira_MG_Brasil_-_Mina_de_Ferro_da_Vale_-_panoramio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Itabira_MG_Brasil_-_Mina_de_Ferro_da_Vale_-_panoramio.jpg/440px-Itabira_MG_Brasil_-_Mina_de_Ferro_da_Vale_-_panoramio.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Itabira_MG_Brasil_-_Mina_de_Ferro_da_Vale_-_panoramio.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Iron mine in <a href="/wiki/Minas_Gerais" title="Minas Gerais">Minas Gerais</a>. Brazil is the world's second largest iron ore exporter.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Mining" title="Mining">Mining</a> is one of the most important economic sectors in South America, especially for Chile, Peru and Bolivia, whose economies are highly dependent on this sector. The continent has large productions of <a href="/wiki/Gold" title="Gold">gold</a> (mainly in Peru, Brazil and Argentina);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[127]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Silver" title="Silver">silver</a> (mainly in Peru, Chile, Bolivia and Argentina);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[128]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Copper" title="Copper">copper</a> (mainly in Chile, Peru and Brazil);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[129]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Iron_ore" title="Iron ore">iron ore</a> (Brazil, Peru and Chile);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[130]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Zinc" title="Zinc">zinc</a> (Peru, Bolivia and Brazil);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[131]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Molybdenum" title="Molybdenum">molybdenum</a> (Chile and Peru);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto7_144-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto7-144">[132]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lithium" title="Lithium">lithium</a> (Chile, Argentina and Brazil);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[133]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lead" title="Lead">lead</a> (Peru and Bolivia);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto9_146-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto9-146">[134]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bauxite" title="Bauxite">bauxite</a> (Brazil);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[135]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tin" title="Tin">tin</a> (Peru, Bolivia and Brazil);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[136]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Manganese" title="Manganese">manganese</a> (Brazil);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[137]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Antimony" title="Antimony">antimony</a> (Bolivia and Ecuador);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[138]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Nickel" title="Nickel">nickel</a> (Brazil);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[139]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Niobium" title="Niobium">niobium</a> (Brazil);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[140]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rhenium" title="Rhenium">rhenium</a> (Chile);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[141]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Iodine" title="Iodine">iodine</a> (Chile),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[142]</a></sup> among others.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a> stands out in the extraction of <a href="/wiki/Iron_ore" title="Iron ore">iron ore</a> (where it is the 2nd largest producer and exporter in the world - iron ore is usually one of the 3 export products that generate the greatest value in the country's trade balance), <a href="/wiki/Copper" title="Copper">copper</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gold" title="Gold">gold</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bauxite" title="Bauxite">bauxite</a> (one of the 5 largest producers in the world), <a href="/wiki/Manganese" title="Manganese">manganese</a> (one of the 5 largest producers in the world), <a href="/wiki/Tin" title="Tin">tin</a> (one of the largest producers in the world), <a href="/wiki/Niobium" title="Niobium">niobium</a> (concentrates 98% of reserves known to the world) and <a href="/wiki/Nickel" title="Nickel">nickel</a>. In terms of gemstones, Brazil is the world's largest producer of <a href="/wiki/Amethyst" title="Amethyst">amethyst</a>, <a href="/wiki/Topaz" title="Topaz">topaz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Agate" title="Agate">agate</a> and one of the main producers of <a href="/wiki/Tourmaline" title="Tourmaline">tourmaline</a>, <a href="/wiki/Emerald" title="Emerald">emerald</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aquamarine_(gemstone)" title="Aquamarine (gemstone)">aquamarine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Garnet" title="Garnet">garnet</a> and <a href="/wiki/Opal" title="Opal">opal</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[143]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[144]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[145]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[146]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159"><a href="#cite_note-159">[147]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[148]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a> contributes about a third of the world <a href="/wiki/Copper" title="Copper">copper</a> production.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[149]</a></sup> In addition to copper, Chile was, in 2019, the world's largest producer of <a href="/wiki/Iodine" title="Iodine">iodine</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[150]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Rhenium" title="Rhenium">rhenium</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[151]</a></sup> the second largest producer of <a href="/wiki/Lithium" title="Lithium">lithium</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto6_164-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto6-164">[152]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Molybdenum" title="Molybdenum">molybdenum</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto7_144-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto7-144">[132]</a></sup> the sixth largest producer of <a href="/wiki/Silver" title="Silver">silver</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto4_165-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto4-165">[153]</a></sup> the seventh largest producer of <a href="/wiki/Salt" title="Salt">salt</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[154]</a></sup> the eighth largest producer of <a href="/wiki/Potash" title="Potash">potash</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[155]</a></sup> the thirteenth producer of <a href="/wiki/Sulfur" title="Sulfur">sulfur</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[156]</a></sup> and the thirteenth producer of <a href="/wiki/Iron_ore" title="Iron ore">iron ore</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[157]</a></sup> in the world.
</p><p>In 2019, <a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru">Peru</a> was the 2nd largest world producer of <a href="/wiki/Copper" title="Copper">copper</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[158]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Silver" title="Silver">silver</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto4_165-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto4-165">[153]</a></sup> 8th largest world producer of <a href="/wiki/Gold" title="Gold">gold</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto8_171-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto8-171">[159]</a></sup> 3rd largest world producer of <a href="/wiki/Lead" title="Lead">lead</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto9_146-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto9-146">[134]</a></sup> 2nd largest world producer of <a href="/wiki/Zinc" title="Zinc">zinc</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[160]</a></sup> 4th largest world producer of <a href="/wiki/Tin" title="Tin">tin</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto12_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto12-173">[161]</a></sup> 5th largest world producer of <a href="/wiki/Boron" title="Boron">boron</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto11_174-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto11-174">[162]</a></sup> and 4th largest world producer of <a href="/wiki/Molybdenum" title="Molybdenum">molybdenum</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto7_144-2"><a href="#cite_note-auto7-144">[132]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2019, <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a> was the 8th largest world producer of <a href="/wiki/Silver" title="Silver">silver</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto4_165-2"><a href="#cite_note-auto4-165">[153]</a></sup> 4th largest world producer of <a href="/wiki/Boron" title="Boron">boron</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto11_174-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto11-174">[162]</a></sup> 5th largest world producer of <a href="/wiki/Antimony" title="Antimony">antimony</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[163]</a></sup> 5th largest world producer of <a href="/wiki/Tin" title="Tin">tin</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto12_173-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto12-173">[161]</a></sup> 6th largest world producer of <a href="/wiki/Tungsten" title="Tungsten">tungsten</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[164]</a></sup> 7th largest producer of <a href="/wiki/Zinc" title="Zinc">zinc</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[165]</a></sup> and the 8th largest producer of <a href="/wiki/Lead" title="Lead">lead</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto9_146-2"><a href="#cite_note-auto9-146">[134]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-campbell_178-0"><a href="#cite_note-campbell-178">[166]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gov.br_179-0"><a href="#cite_note-gov.br-179">[167]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2019, <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a> was the 4th largest world producer of <a href="/wiki/Lithium" title="Lithium">lithium</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto6_164-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto6-164">[152]</a></sup> the 9th largest world producer of <a href="/wiki/Silver" title="Silver">silver</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto4_165-3"><a href="#cite_note-auto4-165">[153]</a></sup> the 17th largest world producer of <a href="/wiki/Gold" title="Gold">gold</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto8_171-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto8-171">[159]</a></sup> and the 7th largest world producer of <a href="/wiki/Boron" title="Boron">boron</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto11_174-2"><a href="#cite_note-auto11-174">[162]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a> is the world's largest producer of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Emeralds" title="Emeralds">emeralds</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[168]</a></sup> In the production of <a href="/wiki/Gold" title="Gold">gold</a>, among 2006 and 2017, the country produced 15 tons per year until 2007, when its production increased significantly, breaking a record of 66.1 tons extracted in 2012. In 2017, it extracted 52.2 tons. The country is among the 25 largest gold producers in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[169]</a></sup> In the production of <a href="/wiki/Silver" title="Silver">silver</a>, in 2017 the country extracted 15,5 tons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-campbell_178-1"><a href="#cite_note-campbell-178">[166]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gov.br_179-1"><a href="#cite_note-gov.br-179">[167]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[170]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the production of <a href="/wiki/Oil" title="Oil">oil</a>, Brazil was the 10th largest oil producer in the world in 2019, with 2.8 million barrels / day. Venezuela was the 21st largest, with 877 thousand barrels / day, Colombia in 22nd with 886 thousand barrels / day, Ecuador in 28th with 531 thousand barrels / day and Argentina 29th with 507 thousand barrels / day. As Venezuela and Ecuador consume little oil and export most of their production, they are part of <a href="/wiki/OPEC" title="OPEC">OPEC</a>. Venezuela had a big drop in production after 2015 (where it produced 2.5 million barrels / day), falling in 2016 to 2.2 million, in 2017 to 2 million, in 2018 to 1.4 million and in 2019 to 877 thousand, due to lack of investments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto3_183-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-183">[171]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the production of <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">natural gas</a>, in 2018, Argentina produced 1524 bcf (billion cubic feet), Venezuela 946, Brazil 877, Bolivia 617, Peru 451, Colombia 379.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[172]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the beginning of 2020, in the production of <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">oil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">natural gas</a>, Brazil exceeded 4 million <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Barrels_of_oil_equivalent" title="Barrels of oil equivalent">barrels of oil equivalent</a> per day, for the first time. In January 2021, 3.168 million barrels of oil per day and 138.753 million cubic meters of natural gas were extracted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto2_185-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-185">[173]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the production of <a href="/wiki/Coal" title="Coal">coal</a>, the continent had 2 of the 30 largest world producers in 2018: Colombia (12th) and Brazil (27th).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto10_186-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto10-186">[174]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Gallery">Gallery</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=South_America&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Gallery">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">

<div class="gallerytext">

<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">

<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 150px;"><div style="margin:35px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:CSN01.jpg" title="Steel-maker CSN, in Volta Redonda. </p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 150px;"><div style="margin:50px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Klabin_Unidade_Puma,_Ortigueira_Paran%C3%A1.jpg" title="Klabin industrial complex, in Ortigueira. Brazil is the second largest pulp producer and the eighth largest paper producer in the world"><img alt="Klabin industrial complex, in Ortigueira. </p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=South_America&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Tourism">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Tourism" title="Tourism">Tourism</a> has increasingly become a significant source of income for many South American countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[175]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[176]</a></sup>
</p><p>Historical relics, architectural and natural wonders, a diverse range of foods and culture, vibrant and colorful cities, and stunning landscapes attract millions of tourists every year to South America. Some of the most visited places in the region are <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Florian%C3%B3polis" title="Florianópolis">Florianópolis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iguazu_Falls" title="Iguazu Falls">Iguazu Falls</a>, <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="São Paulo">São Paulo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arma%C3%A7%C3%A3o_dos_B%C3%BAzios" title="Armação dos Búzios">Armação dos Búzios</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salvador,_Bahia" title="Salvador, Bahia">Salvador</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bombinhas" title="Bombinhas">Bombinhas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Angra_dos_Reis" title="Angra dos Reis">Angra dos Reis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Balne%C3%A1rio_Cambori%C3%BA" title="Balneário Camboriú">Balneário Camboriú</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paraty" title="Paraty">Paraty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ipojuca" title="Ipojuca">Ipojuca</a>, <a href="/wiki/Natal,_Rio_Grande_do_Norte" title="Natal, Rio Grande do Norte">Natal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cairu" title="Cairu">Cairu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fortaleza" title="Fortaleza">Fortaleza</a> and <a href="/wiki/Itapema" title="Itapema">Itapema</a> in Brazil;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[177]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires" title="Buenos Aires">Buenos Aires</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bariloche" title="Bariloche">Bariloche</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salta" title="Salta">Salta</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jujuy" title="Jujuy">Jujuy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Perito_Moreno_Glacier" title="Perito Moreno Glacier">Perito Moreno Glacier</a>, <a href="/wiki/Valdes_Peninsula" title="Valdes Peninsula">Valdes Peninsula</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jesuit_missions_among_the_Guaran%C3%AD#Jesuit_reductions_by_country" title="Jesuit missions among the Guaraní">Guarani Jesuit Missions in the cities of Misiones and Corrientes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ischigualasto_Provincial_Park" title="Ischigualasto Provincial Park">Ischigualasto Provincial Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ushuaia" title="Ushuaia">Ushuaia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Patagonia" title="Patagonia">Patagonia</a> in Argentina;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[178]</a></sup>
<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Isla_Margarita" title="Isla Margarita">Isla Margarita</a>, <a href="/wiki/Angel_Falls" title="Angel Falls">Angel Falls</a>,  <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Los_Roques_archipelago" title="Los Roques archipelago">Los Roques archipelago</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gran_Sabana" title="Gran Sabana">Gran Sabana</a> in Venezuela; <a href="/wiki/Machu_Picchu" title="Machu Picchu">Machu Picchu</a>,  <a href="/wiki/Lima" title="Lima">Lima</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nazca_Lines" title="Nazca Lines">Nazca Lines</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cuzco" title="Cuzco">Cuzco</a> in Peru; <a href="/wiki/Lake_Titicaca" title="Lake Titicaca">Lake Titicaca</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salar_de_Uyuni" title="Salar de Uyuni">Salar de Uyuni</a>, <a href="/wiki/La_Paz" title="La Paz">La Paz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jesuit_Missions_of_Chiquitos" title="Jesuit Missions of Chiquitos">Jesuit Missions of Chiquitos</a> in Bolivia; <a href="/wiki/Tayrona_National_Natural_Park" title="Tayrona National Natural Park">Tayrona National Natural Park</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Santa_Marta,_Colombia" title="Santa Marta, Colombia">Santa Marta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bogot%C3%A1" title="Bogotá">Bogotá</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cali" title="Cali">Cali</a>, <a href="/wiki/Medell%C3%ADn" title="Medellín">Medellín</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cartagena,_Colombia" title="Cartagena, Colombia">Cartagena</a> in Colombia, and the <a href="/wiki/Gal%C3%A1pagos_Islands" title="Galápagos Islands">Galápagos Islands</a> in Ecuador.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[179]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[180]</a></sup> In 2016 Brazil hosted the <a href="/wiki/2016_Summer_Olympics" title="2016 Summer Olympics">2016 Summer Olympics</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;overflow:hidden;width:auto;max-width:1008px"><div class="thumbinner"><div class="noresize" style="overflow:auto"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:67_-_Carthag%C3%A8ne_-_D%C3%A9cembre_2008.jpg" title="Panorama of Cartagena (2008), a major port on the northern coast of Colombia and one of the country's main tourist destinations."><img alt="" data-file-height="3758" data-file-width="19695" decoding="async" height="191" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/67_-_Carthag%C3%A8ne_-_D%C3%A9cembre_2008.jpg/1000px-67_-_Carthag%C3%A8ne_-_D%C3%A9cembre_2008.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/67_-_Carthag%C3%A8ne_-_D%C3%A9cembre_2008.jpg/1500px-67_-_Carthag%C3%A8ne_-_D%C3%A9cembre_2008.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/67_-_Carthag%C3%A8ne_-_D%C3%A9cembre_2008.jpg/2000px-67_-_Carthag%C3%A8ne_-_D%C3%A9cembre_2008.jpg 2x" width="1000"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:67_-_Carthag%C3%A8ne_-_D%C3%A9cembre_2008.jpg" title="File:67 - Carthagène - Décembre 2008.jpg"> </a></div>Panorama of <a href="/wiki/Cartagena,_Colombia" title="Cartagena, Colombia">Cartagena</a> (2008), a major port on the northern coast of <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a> and one of the country's main tourist destinations.</div></div></div>
