<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=South_America&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Culture">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:492px;max-width:492px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:152px;max-width:152px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:89px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2016_fachada_columnas_Teatro_Sol%C3%ADs_de_Montevideo.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3888" data-file-width="5184" decoding="async" height="113" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/2016_fachada_columnas_Teatro_Sol%C3%ADs_de_Montevideo.jpg/150px-2016_fachada_columnas_Teatro_Sol%C3%ADs_de_Montevideo.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/2016_fachada_columnas_Teatro_Sol%C3%ADs_de_Montevideo.jpg/225px-2016_fachada_columnas_Teatro_Sol%C3%ADs_de_Montevideo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/2016_fachada_columnas_Teatro_Sol%C3%ADs_de_Montevideo.jpg/300px-2016_fachada_columnas_Teatro_Sol%C3%ADs_de_Montevideo.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Teatro Solis, Uruguay.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:152px;max-width:152px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:89px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:0200_years_Biblioteca_Nacional_in_Rio_de_Janeiro_city.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1559" data-file-width="2362" decoding="async" height="99" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/0200_years_Biblioteca_Nacional_in_Rio_de_Janeiro_city.jpg/150px-0200_years_Biblioteca_Nacional_in_Rio_de_Janeiro_city.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/0200_years_Biblioteca_Nacional_in_Rio_de_Janeiro_city.jpg/225px-0200_years_Biblioteca_Nacional_in_Rio_de_Janeiro_city.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/0200_years_Biblioteca_Nacional_in_Rio_de_Janeiro_city.jpg/300px-0200_years_Biblioteca_Nacional_in_Rio_de_Janeiro_city.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Biblioteca_Nacional_do_Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Biblioteca Nacional do Rio de Janeiro">National Library</a>, Brazil.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:182px;max-width:182px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:89px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:P1060656a.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1195" data-file-width="2124" decoding="async" height="101" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/P1060656a.jpg/180px-P1060656a.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/P1060656a.jpg/270px-P1060656a.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/P1060656a.jpg/360px-P1060656a.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Arya_Dewaker" title="Arya Dewaker">Arya Dewaker</a> Hindu temple, <a href="/wiki/Paramaribo" title="Paramaribo">Paramaribo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Suriname" title="Suriname">Suriname</a>.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>South Americans are culturally influenced by their indigenous peoples, the historic connection with the Iberian Peninsula and Africa, and waves of immigrants from around the globe.
</p><p>
South American nations have a rich variety of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Latin_American_music" title="Latin American music">music</a>. Some of the most famous genres include <a href="/wiki/Vallenato" title="Vallenato">vallenato</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cumbia" title="Cumbia">cumbia</a> from Colombia, <a href="/wiki/Pasillo" title="Pasillo">pasillo</a> from Colombia and Ecuador, <a href="/wiki/Samba" title="Samba">samba</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bossa_nova" title="Bossa nova">bossa nova</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/M%C3%BAsica_sertaneja" title="Música sertaneja">música sertaneja</a> from Brazil, <a href="/wiki/Joropo" title="Joropo">joropo</a> from Venezuela and <a href="/wiki/Tango_music" title="Tango music">tango</a> from Argentina and Uruguay. Also well known is the non-commercial folk genre <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nueva_Canci%C3%B3n" title="Nueva Canción">Nueva Canción</a> movement which was founded in Argentina and Chile and quickly spread to the rest of the Latin America. <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></p><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:144px;max-width:144px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:185px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tango-Show-Buenos-Aires-01.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3072" data-file-width="2304" decoding="async" height="189" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Tango-Show-Buenos-Aires-01.jpg/142px-Tango-Show-Buenos-Aires-01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Tango-Show-Buenos-Aires-01.jpg/213px-Tango-Show-Buenos-Aires-01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Tango-Show-Buenos-Aires-01.jpg/284px-Tango-Show-Buenos-Aires-01.jpg 2x" width="142"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Tango" title="Tango">Tango</a> show in <a href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires" title="Buenos Aires">Buenos Aires</a>, typical Argentine dance.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:144px;max-width:144px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:185px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Carmen_Miranda_1941.JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="1245" data-file-width="957" decoding="async" height="185" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Carmen_Miranda_1941.JPG/142px-Carmen_Miranda_1941.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Carmen_Miranda_1941.JPG/213px-Carmen_Miranda_1941.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Carmen_Miranda_1941.JPG/284px-Carmen_Miranda_1941.JPG 2x" width="142"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Carmen_Miranda" title="Carmen Miranda">Carmen Miranda</a>, Portuguese Brazilian singer helped popularize <a href="/wiki/Samba" title="Samba">samba</a> internationally.</div></div></div></div></div><p> People on the Peruvian coast created the fine <a href="/wiki/Guitar" title="Guitar">guitar</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cajon" title="Cajon">cajon</a> duos or trios in the most <a href="/wiki/Mestizo" title="Mestizo">mestizo</a> (mixed) of South American rhythms such as the Marinera (from Lima), the <a href="/wiki/Tondero" title="Tondero">Tondero</a> (from Piura), the 19th-century popular Creole Valse or Peruvian Valse, the soulful Arequipan Yaravi, and the early-20th-century Paraguayan <a href="/wiki/Guarania_(music)" title="Guarania (music)">Guarania</a>. In the late 20th century, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rock_en_Espa%C3%B1ol" title="Rock en Español">Spanish rock</a> emerged by young hipsters influenced by British pop and American rock. <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Brazil" title="Music of Brazil">Brazil</a> has a Portuguese-language pop rock industry as well a great variety of other music genres. In the central and western regions of Bolivia, Andean and folklore music like <a href="/wiki/Diablada" title="Diablada">Diablada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Caporales" title="Caporales">Caporales</a> and <a href="/wiki/Morenada" title="Morenada">Morenada</a> are the most representative of the country, which were originated by European, Aymara and Quechua influences.
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spanish_American_literature" title="Spanish American literature">literature</a> of South America has attracted considerable critical and popular acclaim, especially with the <a href="/wiki/Latin_American_Boom" title="Latin American Boom">Latin American Boom</a> of the 1960s and 1970s, and the rise of authors such as <a href="/wiki/Mario_Vargas_Llosa" title="Mario Vargas Llosa">Mario Vargas Llosa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gabriel_Garc%C3%ADa_M%C3%A1rquez" title="Gabriel García Márquez">Gabriel García Márquez</a> in novels and <a href="/wiki/Jorge_Luis_Borges" title="Jorge Luis Borges">Jorge Luis Borges</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pablo_Neruda" title="Pablo Neruda">Pablo Neruda</a> in other genres. The Brazilians <a href="/wiki/Machado_de_Assis" title="Machado de Assis">Machado de Assis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jo%C3%A3o_Guimar%C3%A3es_Rosa" title="João Guimarães Rosa">João Guimarães Rosa</a> are widely regarded as the greatest Brazilian writers.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Food_and_drink">Food and drink</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=South_America&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Food and drink">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cuisine_of_South_America" title="Cuisine of South America">Cuisine of South America</a></div>
<p>Because of South America's broad ethnic mix, <a href="/wiki/South_American_cuisine" title="South American cuisine">South American cuisine</a> has African, Mestizo, South Asian, East Asian, and European influences. <a href="/wiki/Bahia" title="Bahia">Bahia</a>, Brazil, is especially well known for its West African–influenced cuisine. Argentines, Chileans, Uruguayans, Brazilians, Bolivians, and Venezuelans regularly consume wine. People in Argentina, Paraguay, Uruguay, southern Chile, Bolivia and Southern Brazil drink <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mate_(beverage)" title="Mate (beverage)">mate</a>, an herb which is brewed. The Paraguayan version, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Terere" title="Terere">terere</a>, differs from other forms of mate in that it is served cold. <a href="/wiki/Pisco" title="Pisco">Pisco</a> is a liquor distilled from grapes in Peru and Chile. Peruvian cuisine mixes elements from Chinese, Japanese, Spanish, Italian, African, Arab, Andean, and Amazonic food.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Plastic_arts">Plastic arts</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=South_America&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Plastic arts">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Art_of_South_America" title="Art of South America">Art of South America</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Fernando_Botero,_Bird_(1990),_Singapore_-_20040616.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Fernando_Botero%2C_Bird_%281990%29%2C_Singapore_-_20040616.jpg/220px-Fernando_Botero%2C_Bird_%281990%29%2C_Singapore_-_20040616.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Fernando_Botero%2C_Bird_%281990%29%2C_Singapore_-_20040616.jpg/330px-Fernando_Botero%2C_Bird_%281990%29%2C_Singapore_-_20040616.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Fernando_Botero%2C_Bird_%281990%29%2C_Singapore_-_20040616.jpg/440px-Fernando_Botero%2C_Bird_%281990%29%2C_Singapore_-_20040616.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Fernando_Botero,_Bird_(1990),_Singapore_-_20040616.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Bird</i> (<a href="/wiki/UOB_Plaza" title="UOB Plaza">UOB Plaza</a>, Singapore), sculpture of Colombian artist <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Botero" title="Fernando Botero">Fernando Botero</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Laberinto_Cromovegetal_-_Universidad_Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Laberinto_Cromovegetal_-_Universidad_Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar.jpg/220px-Laberinto_Cromovegetal_-_Universidad_Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Laberinto_Cromovegetal_-_Universidad_Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar.jpg/330px-Laberinto_Cromovegetal_-_Universidad_Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Laberinto_Cromovegetal_-_Universidad_Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar.jpg/440px-Laberinto_Cromovegetal_-_Universidad_Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Laberinto_Cromovegetal_-_Universidad_Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>"Chromovegetal Maze" by <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Cruz-Diez" title="Carlos Cruz-Diez">Carlos Cruz Diez</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Caracas" title="Caracas">Caracas</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The artist <a href="/wiki/Oswaldo_Guayasam%C3%ADn" title="Oswaldo Guayasamín">Oswaldo Guayasamín</a> (1919–1999) from <a href="/wiki/Ecuador" title="Ecuador">Ecuador</a>, represented with his painting style the feeling of the peoples of Latin America<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[181]</a></sup> highlighting social injustices in various parts of the world. The Colombian <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Botero" title="Fernando Botero">Fernando Botero</a> (1932) is one of the greatest exponents of painting and sculpture that continues still active and has been able to develop a recognizable style of his own.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[182]</a></sup> For his part, the Venezuelan <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Cruz-Diez" title="Carlos Cruz-Diez">Carlos Cruz-Diez</a> has contributed significantly to contemporary art,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[183]</a></sup> with the presence of works around the world.
</p><p>Currently several emerging South American artists are recognized by international art critics: <a href="/wiki/Guillermo_Lora" title="Guillermo Lora">Guillermo Lorca</a> – Chilean painter,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[184]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[185]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Teddy_Cobe%C3%B1a" title="Teddy Cobeña">Teddy Cobeña</a> – Ecuadorian sculptor and recipient of international sculpture award in <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[186]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[187]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[188]</a></sup> and Argentine artist <a href="/wiki/Adri%C3%A1n_Villar_Rojas" title="Adrián Villar Rojas">Adrián Villar Rojas</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[189]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[190]</a></sup> – winner of the Zurich Museum Art Award among many others.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sport">Sport</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=South_America&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Sport">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_South_America" title="Sport in South America">Sport in South America</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Aerea2_maracana.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2667" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Aerea2_maracana.jpg/220px-Aerea2_maracana.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Aerea2_maracana.jpg/330px-Aerea2_maracana.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Aerea2_maracana.jpg/440px-Aerea2_maracana.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Aerea2_maracana.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Maracan%C3%A3_Stadium" title="Maracanã Stadium">Maracanã Stadium</a> in <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a>, Brazil</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stadion_Rio_de_Janeiro_Finale_WM_2014_(22117945206).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2436" data-file-width="5485" decoding="async" height="98" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Stadion_Rio_de_Janeiro_Finale_WM_2014_%2822117945206%29.jpg/220px-Stadion_Rio_de_Janeiro_Finale_WM_2014_%2822117945206%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Stadion_Rio_de_Janeiro_Finale_WM_2014_%2822117945206%29.jpg/330px-Stadion_Rio_de_Janeiro_Finale_WM_2014_%2822117945206%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Stadion_Rio_de_Janeiro_Finale_WM_2014_%2822117945206%29.jpg/440px-Stadion_Rio_de_Janeiro_Finale_WM_2014_%2822117945206%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Stadion_Rio_de_Janeiro_Finale_WM_2014_(22117945206).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Panorama of the interior of the Maracanã stadium during the closing ceremony of the <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2014 FIFA World Cup">2014 FIFA World Cup</a></div></div></div>
<p>A wide range of sports are played in the continent of South America, with <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">football</a> being the most popular overall, while <a href="/wiki/Baseball" title="Baseball">baseball</a> is the most popular in Venezuela.
</p><p>Other sports include <a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">basketball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cycle_sport" title="Cycle sport">cycling</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polo" title="Polo">polo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Volleyball" title="Volleyball">volleyball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Futsal" title="Futsal">futsal</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Motorsports" title="Motorsports">motorsports</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rugby_football" title="Rugby football">rugby</a> (mostly in Argentina and Uruguay), <a href="/wiki/Handball" title="Handball">handball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">tennis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Golf" title="Golf">golf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Field_hockey" title="Field hockey">field hockey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">boxing</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cricket" title="Cricket">cricket</a>.
</p><p>South America hosted its first <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">Olympic Games</a> in <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a>, Brazil, in 2016, and has hosted the <a href="/wiki/Youth_Olympic_Games" title="Youth Olympic Games">Youth Olympic Games</a> in <a href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires" title="Buenos Aires">Buenos Aires</a>, Argentina, in 2018.
</p><p>South America shares with Europe supremacy over the sport of football as all winners in <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">FIFA World Cup</a> history and all winning teams in the <a href="/wiki/FIFA_Club_World_Cup" title="FIFA Club World Cup">FIFA Club World Cup</a> have come from these two continents. Brazil holds the record for most times winning the FIFA World Cup with five titles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[191]</a></sup> Argentina and Uruguay have two titles each. So far five South American nations have hosted the tournament including the first edition in Uruguay (1930). Two were from Brazil (1950, 2014), Chile (1962), and Argentina (1978).
</p><p>South America is home to the longest-running international football tournament, the <a href="/wiki/Copa_Am%C3%A9rica" title="Copa América">Copa América</a>, which has been contested since 1916. Argentina and Uruguay have <a href="/wiki/List_of_Copa_Am%C3%A9rica_finals" title="List of Copa América finals">won the Copa América</a> 15 times each, the most among all countries.
</p><p>Also, in South America, a multi-sport event, the <a href="/wiki/South_American_Games" title="South American Games">South American Games</a>, are held every four years. The first edition was held in <a href="/wiki/La_Paz" title="La Paz">La Paz</a> in 1978 and the most recent took place in <a href="/wiki/Santiago" title="Santiago">Santiago</a> in 2014.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/South_American_Cricket_Championship" title="South American Cricket Championship">South American Cricket Championship</a> is an international <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Limited-overs_cricket" title="Limited-overs cricket">one-day cricket</a> tournament played since 1995 featuring national teams from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sports_in_South_America" title="Sports in South America">South America</a> and certain other invited sides including teams from North America, currently played annually but until 2013 was usually played every two seasons.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=South_America&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: Infrastructure">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Aerogeneradores_en_Punto_Fijo.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1414" data-file-width="2121" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Aerogeneradores_en_Punto_Fijo.jpg/220px-Aerogeneradores_en_Punto_Fijo.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Aerogeneradores_en_Punto_Fijo.jpg/330px-Aerogeneradores_en_Punto_Fijo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Aerogeneradores_en_Punto_Fijo.jpg/440px-Aerogeneradores_en_Punto_Fijo.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Aerogeneradores_en_Punto_Fijo.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Wind farm in the <a href="/wiki/Paraguan%C3%A1_Peninsula" title="Paraguaná Peninsula">Paraguaná Peninsula</a>, Venezuela</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=South_America&amp;action=edit&amp;section=33" title="Edit section: Energy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Due to the diversity of <a href="/wiki/Topography" title="Topography">topography</a> and pluviometric precipitation conditions, the region's water resources vary enormously in different areas. In the <a href="/wiki/Andes" title="Andes">Andes</a>, navigation possibilities are limited, except for the Magdalena River, <a href="/wiki/Lake_Titicaca" title="Lake Titicaca">Lake Titicaca</a> and the lakes of the southern regions of Chile and Argentina. Irrigation is an important factor for agriculture from northwestern Peru to Patagonia. Less than 10% of the known electrical potential of the Andes had been used until the mid-1960s.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Highlands" title="Brazilian Highlands">Brazilian Highlands</a> have a much higher hydroelectric potential than the <a href="/wiki/Andes" title="Andes">Andean region</a><sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>  and its possibilities of exploitation are greater due to the existence of several large rivers with high margins and the occurrence of great differences forming huge cataracts, such as those of Paulo Afonso, Iguaçu and others. The <a href="/wiki/Amazon_River" title="Amazon River">Amazon River</a> system has about 13,000 km of waterways, but its possibilities for hydroelectric use are still unknown.
</p><p>Most of the continent's energy is generated through <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hydroelectric_power_plants" title="Hydroelectric power plants">hydroelectric power plants</a>, but there is also an important share of <a href="/wiki/Thermoelectric_effect" title="Thermoelectric effect">thermoelectric</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wind_energy" title="Wind energy">wind energy</a>. Brazil and Argentina are the only South American countries that generate <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power" title="Nuclear power">nuclear power</a>, each with two <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_plants" title="Nuclear power plants">nuclear power plants</a>. In 1991 these countries signed a peaceful nuclear cooperation agreement.
</p>
<div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;overflow:hidden;width:auto;max-width:1508px"><div class="thumbinner"><div class="noresize" style="overflow:auto"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Itaipu_D%C3%A9cembre_2007_-_Vue_G%C3%A9n%C3%A9rale.jpg" title="Panoramic view of the Itaipu Dam, the second largest of the world in energy production."><img alt="" data-file-height="1275" data-file-width="10630" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Itaipu_D%C3%A9cembre_2007_-_Vue_G%C3%A9n%C3%A9rale.jpg/1500px-Itaipu_D%C3%A9cembre_2007_-_Vue_G%C3%A9n%C3%A9rale.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Itaipu_D%C3%A9cembre_2007_-_Vue_G%C3%A9n%C3%A9rale.jpg/2250px-Itaipu_D%C3%A9cembre_2007_-_Vue_G%C3%A9n%C3%A9rale.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Itaipu_D%C3%A9cembre_2007_-_Vue_G%C3%A9n%C3%A9rale.jpg/3000px-Itaipu_D%C3%A9cembre_2007_-_Vue_G%C3%A9n%C3%A9rale.jpg 2x" width="1500"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Itaipu_D%C3%A9cembre_2007_-_Vue_G%C3%A9n%C3%A9rale.jpg" title="File:Itaipu Décembre 2007 - Vue Générale.jpg"> </a></div>Panoramic view of the <a href="/wiki/Itaipu_Dam" title="Itaipu Dam">Itaipu Dam</a>, the second largest of the world in energy production.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Energia_Eolica.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2554" data-file-width="3467" decoding="async" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Energia_Eolica.jpg/220px-Energia_Eolica.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Energia_Eolica.jpg/330px-Energia_Eolica.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Energia_Eolica.jpg/440px-Energia_Eolica.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Energia_Eolica.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Wind_power" title="Wind power">Wind power</a> in <a href="/wiki/Parna%C3%ADba" title="Parnaíba">Parnaíba</a>.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Angra_dos_Reis_-_usinas_nucleares.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3072" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Angra_dos_Reis_-_usinas_nucleares.jpg/220px-Angra_dos_Reis_-_usinas_nucleares.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Angra_dos_Reis_-_usinas_nucleares.jpg/330px-Angra_dos_Reis_-_usinas_nucleares.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Angra_dos_Reis_-_usinas_nucleares.jpg/440px-Angra_dos_Reis_-_usinas_nucleares.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Angra_dos_Reis_-_usinas_nucleares.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Angra_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Angra Nuclear Power Plant">Angra Nuclear Power Plant</a> in <a href="/wiki/Angra_dos_Reis" title="Angra dos Reis">Angra dos Reis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro_(state)" title="Rio de Janeiro (state)">Rio de Janeiro</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Usina_solar_de_Pirapora_2.gif"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1067" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Usina_solar_de_Pirapora_2.gif/220px-Usina_solar_de_Pirapora_2.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Usina_solar_de_Pirapora_2.gif/330px-Usina_solar_de_Pirapora_2.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Usina_solar_de_Pirapora_2.gif/440px-Usina_solar_de_Pirapora_2.gif 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Usina_solar_de_Pirapora_2.gif" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Pirapora Solar Complex, the largest in Brazil and Latin America with a capacity of 321 MW.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cerro_Dominador.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="820" data-file-width="1273" decoding="async" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Cerro_Dominador.jpg/220px-Cerro_Dominador.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Cerro_Dominador.jpg/330px-Cerro_Dominador.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Cerro_Dominador.jpg/440px-Cerro_Dominador.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cerro_Dominador.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Cerro Dominador Solar Thermal Plant</div></div></div>
<p>The Brazilian government has undertaken an ambitious program to reduce dependence on imported petroleum. Imports previously accounted for more than 70% of the country's oil needs but Brazil became self-sufficient in oil in 2006–2007. Brazil was the 10th largest oil producer in the world in 2019, with 2.8 million barrels / day. Production manages to supply the country's demand.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto3_183-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-183">[171]</a></sup> In the beginning of 2020, in the production of <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">oil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">natural gas</a>, the country exceeded 4 million barrels of oil equivalent per day, for the first time. In January this year, 3.168 million barrels of oil per day and 138.753 million cubic meters of natural gas were extracted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto2_185-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-185">[173]</a></sup>
</p><p>Brazil is one of the main world producers of <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectricity" title="Hydroelectricity">hydroelectric power</a>. In 2019, Brazil had 217 hydroelectric plants in operation, with an installed capacity of 98,581 MW, 60.16% of the country's energy generation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[192]</a></sup> In the total generation of electricity, in 2019 Brazil reached 170,000 megawatts of installed capacity, more than 75% from renewable sources (the majority, hydroelectric).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[193]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[194]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2013, the <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Region,_Brazil" title="Southeast Region, Brazil">Southeast Region</a> used about 50% of the load of the National Integrated System (SIN), being the main energy consuming region in the country. The region's installed electricity generation capacity totaled almost 42,500 MW, which represented about a third of Brazil's generation capacity. The hydroelectric generation represented 58% of the region's installed capacity, with the remaining 42% corresponding basically to the thermoelectric generation. São Paulo accounted for 40% of this capacity; Minas Gerais by about 25%; Rio de Janeiro by 13.3%; and Espírito Santo accounted for the rest. The <a href="/wiki/South_Region,_Brazil" title="South Region, Brazil">South Region</a> owns the <a href="/wiki/Itaipu_Dam" title="Itaipu Dam">Itaipu Dam</a>, which was the largest hydroelectric plant in the world for several years, until the inauguration of <a href="/wiki/Three_Gorges_Dam" title="Three Gorges Dam">Three Gorges Dam</a> in China. It remains the second largest operating hydroelectric in the world. Brazil is the co-owner of the Itaipu Plant with <a href="/wiki/Paraguay" title="Paraguay">Paraguay</a>: the dam is located on the <a href="/wiki/Paran%C3%A1_River" title="Paraná River">Paraná River</a>, located on the border between countries. It has an installed generation capacity of 14 <a href="/wiki/Watt" title="Watt">GW</a> for 20 generating units of 700 <a href="/wiki/Watt" title="Watt">MW</a> each. <a href="/wiki/North_Region,_Brazil" title="North Region, Brazil">North Region</a> has large hydroelectric plants, such as <a href="/wiki/Belo_Monte_Dam" title="Belo Monte Dam">Belo Monte Dam</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tucuru%C3%AD_Dam" title="Tucuruí Dam">Tucuruí Dam</a>, which produce much of the national energy. Brazil's hydroelectric potential has not yet been fully exploited, so the country still has the capacity to build several renewable energy plants in its territory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[195]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[196]</a></sup>
</p><p>As of July 2022,<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag ref" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="http://www.ons.org.br/paginas/conhecimento/acervo-digital/documentos-e-publicacoes" rel="nofollow">[ref]</a></sup> according to ONS, total installed capacity of <a href="/wiki/Wind_power" title="Wind power">wind power</a> was 22 GW, with average <a href="/wiki/Capacity_factor" title="Capacity factor">capacity factor</a> of 58%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[197]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[198]</a></sup> While the world average wind production capacity factors is 24.7%, there are areas in Northern Brazil, specially in Bahia State, where some wind farms record with average capacity factors over 60%;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[199]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_212-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-212">[200]</a></sup> the average capacity factor in the <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Region,_Brazil" title="Northeast Region, Brazil">Northeast Region</a> is 45% in the coast and 49% in the interior.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[201]</a></sup> In 2019, wind energy represented 9% of the energy generated in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_214-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto-214">[202]</a></sup> In 2019, it was estimated that the country had an estimated wind power generation potential of around 522 GW (this, only onshore), enough energy to meet three times the country's current demand.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[203]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[204]</a></sup> In 2020 Brazil was the 8th country in the world in terms of installed wind power (17.2 GW).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto5_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto5-217">[205]</a></sup>
</p><p>Nuclear energy accounts for about 4% of Brazil's electricity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-uic_218-0"><a href="#cite_note-uic-218">[206]</a></sup> The nuclear power generation monopoly is owned by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eletronuclear" title="Eletronuclear">Eletronuclear (Eletrobrás Eletronuclear S/A)</a>, a wholly owned subsidiary of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eletrobr%C3%A1s" title="Eletrobrás">Eletrobrás</a>. Nuclear energy is produced by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_nuclear_reactors#Brazil" title="List of nuclear reactors">two reactors</a> at <a href="/wiki/Angra_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Angra Nuclear Power Plant">Angra</a>. It is located at the Central Nuclear Almirante Álvaro Alberto (CNAAA) on the Praia de Itaorna in <a href="/wiki/Angra_dos_Reis" title="Angra dos Reis">Angra dos Reis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro_(state)" title="Rio de Janeiro (state)">Rio de Janeiro</a>. It consists of two <a href="/wiki/Pressurized_water_reactor" title="Pressurized water reactor">pressurized water reactors</a>, Angra I, with capacity of 657 MW, connected to the power grid in 1982, and Angra II, with capacity of 1,350 MW, connected in 2000. A third reactor, Angra III, with a projected output of 1,350 MW, is planned to be finished.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-merco_219-0"><a href="#cite_note-merco-219">[207]</a></sup>
</p><p>As of August 2022,<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag ref" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="http://www.ons.org.br/paginas/conhecimento/acervo-digital/documentos-e-publicacoes" rel="nofollow">[ref]</a></sup> according to ONS, total installed capacity of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Photovoltaic_solar" title="Photovoltaic solar">photovoltaic solar</a> was 17 GW, with average <a href="/wiki/Capacity_factor" title="Capacity factor">capacity factor</a> of 23%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[208]</a></sup>
<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[209]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[210]</a></sup> Some of the most <a href="/wiki/Solar_irradiance" title="Solar irradiance">irradiated</a> Brazilian States are MG ("Minas Gerais"), BA ("Bahia") and GO (Goiás), which have indeed world <a href="/wiki/Solar_irradiance" title="Solar irradiance">irradiation</a> level records.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[211]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_212-1"><a href="#cite_note-:0-212">[200]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[212]</a></sup> In 2019, solar power represented 1.27% of the energy generated in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_214-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto-214">[202]</a></sup> In 2020, Brazil was the 14th country in the world in terms of installed solar power (7.8 GW).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto5_217-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto5-217">[205]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2020, Brazil was the 2nd largest country in the world in the production of energy through <a href="/wiki/Biomass" title="Biomass">biomass</a> (energy production from solid biofuels and renewable waste), with 15,2 GW installed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[213]</a></sup>
</p><p>After Brazil, <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a> is the country in South America that most stands out in energy production. In 2020, the country was the 20th largest petroleum producer in the world, and in 2015 it was the 19th largest exporter. In natural gas, the country was, in 2015, the 40th largest producer in the world. Colombia's biggest highlight is in coal, where the country was, in 2018, the world's 12th largest producer and the 5th largest exporter. In renewable energies, in 2020, the country ranked 45th in the world in terms of installed wind energy (0.5 GW), 76th in the world in terms of installed solar energy (0.1 GW) and 20th in the world in terms of installed hydroelectric power (12.6 GW). <a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela">Venezuela</a>, which was one of the world's largest oil producers (about 2.5 million barrels/day in 2015) and one of the largest exporters, due to its political problems, has had its production drastically reduced in recent years: in 2016, it dropped to 2.2 million, in 2017 to 2 million, in 2018 to 1.4 million and in 2019 to 877 thousand, reaching only 300,000 barrels/day at a given point. The country also stands out in hydroelectricity, where it was the 14th country in the world in terms of installed capacity in 2020 (16,5 GW). <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a> was, in 2017, the 18th largest producer in the world, and the largest producer in Latin America, of natural gas, in addition to being the 28th largest oil producer; although the country has the Vaca Muerta field, which holds close to 16 billion barrels of technically recoverable shale oil, and is the second largest shale natural gas deposit in the world, the country lacks the capacity to exploit the deposit: it is necessary capital, technology and knowledge that can only come from offshore energy companies, who view Argentina and its erratic economic policies with considerable suspicion, not wanting to invest in the country. In renewable energies, in 2020, the country ranked 27th in the world in terms of installed wind energy (2.6 GW), 42nd in the world in terms of installed solar energy (0.7 GW) and 21st in the world in terms of installed hydroelectric power (11.3 GW). The country has great future potential for the production of wind energy in the Patagonia region. <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a>, although currently not a major energy producer, has great future potential for solar energy production in the Atacama Desert region. <a href="/wiki/Paraguay" title="Paraguay">Paraguay</a> stands out today in hydroelectric production thanks to the Itaipu Power Plant. <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a> stand out in the production of natural gas, where it was the 31st largest in the world in 2015. <a href="/wiki/Ecuador" title="Ecuador">Ecuador</a>, because it consumes little energy, is part of OPEC and was the 27th largest oil producer in the world in 2020, being the 22nd largest exporter in 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[214]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[215]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[216]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto10_186-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto10-186">[174]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto5_217-2"><a href="#cite_note-auto5-217">[205]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=South_America&amp;action=edit&amp;section=34" title="Edit section: Transport">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:RodBandeirantes.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2194" data-file-width="3504" decoding="async" height="138" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/RodBandeirantes.jpg/220px-RodBandeirantes.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/RodBandeirantes.jpg/330px-RodBandeirantes.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/RodBandeirantes.jpg/440px-RodBandeirantes.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:RodBandeirantes.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Rodovia_dos_Bandeirantes" title="Rodovia dos Bandeirantes">Rodovia dos Bandeirantes</a>, Brazil</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ruta_Nacional_9_en_Z%C3%A1rate_hacia_el_noroeste.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2134" data-file-width="2848" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Ruta_Nacional_9_en_Z%C3%A1rate_hacia_el_noroeste.jpg/220px-Ruta_Nacional_9_en_Z%C3%A1rate_hacia_el_noroeste.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Ruta_Nacional_9_en_Z%C3%A1rate_hacia_el_noroeste.jpg/330px-Ruta_Nacional_9_en_Z%C3%A1rate_hacia_el_noroeste.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Ruta_Nacional_9_en_Z%C3%A1rate_hacia_el_noroeste.jpg/440px-Ruta_Nacional_9_en_Z%C3%A1rate_hacia_el_noroeste.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ruta_Nacional_9_en_Z%C3%A1rate_hacia_el_noroeste.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ruta 9 / 14, in <a href="/wiki/Z%C3%A1rate,_Buenos_Aires" title="Zárate, Buenos Aires">Zarate</a>, Argentina</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ilha_de_Mocangu%C3%AA_by_Diego_Baravelli_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2087" data-file-width="3267" decoding="async" height="141" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Ilha_de_Mocangu%C3%AA_by_Diego_Baravelli_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Ilha_de_Mocangu%C3%AA_by_Diego_Baravelli_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Ilha_de_Mocangu%C3%AA_by_Diego_Baravelli_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-Ilha_de_Mocangu%C3%AA_by_Diego_Baravelli_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Ilha_de_Mocangu%C3%AA_by_Diego_Baravelli_%28cropped%29.jpg/440px-Ilha_de_Mocangu%C3%AA_by_Diego_Baravelli_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ilha_de_Mocangu%C3%AA_by_Diego_Baravelli_(cropped).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Rio%E2%80%93Niter%C3%B3i_Bridge" title="Rio–Niterói Bridge">Rio–Niterói Bridge</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Riodejaneiro_aerea_aeroportogaleao-131756(cut).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2254" data-file-width="2885" decoding="async" height="172" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Riodejaneiro_aerea_aeroportogaleao-131756%28cut%29.jpg/220px-Riodejaneiro_aerea_aeroportogaleao-131756%28cut%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Riodejaneiro_aerea_aeroportogaleao-131756%28cut%29.jpg/330px-Riodejaneiro_aerea_aeroportogaleao-131756%28cut%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Riodejaneiro_aerea_aeroportogaleao-131756%28cut%29.jpg/440px-Riodejaneiro_aerea_aeroportogaleao-131756%28cut%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Riodejaneiro_aerea_aeroportogaleao-131756(cut).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro_International_Airport" title="Rio de Janeiro International Airport">Rio de Janeiro International Airport</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:A_Sa%C3%BAde_dos_Portos_(7110638275).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="667" decoding="async" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/A_Sa%C3%BAde_dos_Portos_%287110638275%29.jpg/170px-A_Sa%C3%BAde_dos_Portos_%287110638275%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/A_Sa%C3%BAde_dos_Portos_%287110638275%29.jpg/255px-A_Sa%C3%BAde_dos_Portos_%287110638275%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/A_Sa%C3%BAde_dos_Portos_%287110638275%29.jpg/340px-A_Sa%C3%BAde_dos_Portos_%287110638275%29.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:A_Sa%C3%BAde_dos_Portos_(7110638275).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Port of Itajaí, Santa Catarina, Brazil</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ruta_Panamericana_Buenos_Aires_Florida.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Ruta_Panamericana_Buenos_Aires_Florida.jpg/220px-Ruta_Panamericana_Buenos_Aires_Florida.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Ruta_Panamericana_Buenos_Aires_Florida.jpg/330px-Ruta_Panamericana_Buenos_Aires_Florida.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Ruta_Panamericana_Buenos_Aires_Florida.jpg/440px-Ruta_Panamericana_Buenos_Aires_Florida.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ruta_Panamericana_Buenos_Aires_Florida.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Stretch of the <a href="/wiki/Pan-American_Highway" title="Pan-American Highway">Pan-American Highway</a> in Argentina</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:General_Rafael_Urdaneta_Bridge_view_from_the_lake_to_Cabimas_side.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2848" data-file-width="4288" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/General_Rafael_Urdaneta_Bridge_view_from_the_lake_to_Cabimas_side.jpg/220px-General_Rafael_Urdaneta_Bridge_view_from_the_lake_to_Cabimas_side.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/General_Rafael_Urdaneta_Bridge_view_from_the_lake_to_Cabimas_side.jpg/330px-General_Rafael_Urdaneta_Bridge_view_from_the_lake_to_Cabimas_side.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/General_Rafael_Urdaneta_Bridge_view_from_the_lake_to_Cabimas_side.jpg/440px-General_Rafael_Urdaneta_Bridge_view_from_the_lake_to_Cabimas_side.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:General_Rafael_Urdaneta_Bridge_view_from_the_lake_to_Cabimas_side.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/General_Rafael_Urdaneta_Bridge" title="General Rafael Urdaneta Bridge">General Rafael Urdaneta Bridge</a> in Venezuela</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Puerto-del-callao.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2897" data-file-width="4345" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Puerto-del-callao.jpg/220px-Puerto-del-callao.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Puerto-del-callao.jpg/330px-Puerto-del-callao.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Puerto-del-callao.jpg/440px-Puerto-del-callao.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Puerto-del-callao.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Port of Callao in Lima</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:L%C3%ADnea_Roja_de_Mi_Telef%C3%A9rico_en_La_Paz,_Bolivia.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2848" data-file-width="4288" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/L%C3%ADnea_Roja_de_Mi_Telef%C3%A9rico_en_La_Paz%2C_Bolivia.jpg/220px-L%C3%ADnea_Roja_de_Mi_Telef%C3%A9rico_en_La_Paz%2C_Bolivia.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/L%C3%ADnea_Roja_de_Mi_Telef%C3%A9rico_en_La_Paz%2C_Bolivia.jpg/330px-L%C3%ADnea_Roja_de_Mi_Telef%C3%A9rico_en_La_Paz%2C_Bolivia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/L%C3%ADnea_Roja_de_Mi_Telef%C3%A9rico_en_La_Paz%2C_Bolivia.jpg/440px-L%C3%ADnea_Roja_de_Mi_Telef%C3%A9rico_en_La_Paz%2C_Bolivia.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:L%C3%ADnea_Roja_de_Mi_Telef%C3%A9rico_en_La_Paz,_Bolivia.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The La Paz cable car system in Bolivia is home to both the longest and highest urban cable car network in the world</div></div></div>
<p>Transport in South America is basically carried out using the <a href="/wiki/Road" title="Road">road</a> mode, the most developed in the region. There is also a considerable infrastructure of <a href="/wiki/Port" title="Port">ports</a> and <a href="/wiki/Airport" title="Airport">airports</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport" title="Rail transport">railway</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fluvial_processes" title="Fluvial processes">fluvial</a> sector, although it has potential, is usually treated in a secondary way.
</p><p>Brazil has more than 1.7 million km of <a href="/wiki/Road" title="Road">roads</a>, of which 215,000 km are paved, and about 14,000 km are <a href="/wiki/Dual_carriageway" title="Dual carriageway">divided highways</a>. The two most important highways in the country are <a href="/wiki/BR-101" title="BR-101">BR-101</a> and <a href="/wiki/BR-116" title="BR-116">BR-116</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto1_229-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-229">[217]</a></sup> Argentina has more than 600,000 km of roads, of which about 70,000 km are paved, and about 2,500 km are divided highways. The three most important highways in the country are <a href="/wiki/National_Route_9_(Argentina)" title="National Route 9 (Argentina)">Route 9</a>, <a href="/wiki/National_Route_7_(Argentina)" title="National Route 7 (Argentina)">Route 7</a> and <a href="/wiki/National_Route_14_(Argentina)" title="National Route 14 (Argentina)">Route 14</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto1_229-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-229">[217]</a></sup> Colombia has about 210,000 km of roads, and about 2,300 km are divided highways.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[218]</a></sup> Chile has about 82,000 km of roads, 20,000 km of which are paved, and about 2,000 km are divided highways. The most important highway in the country is the <a href="/wiki/Chile_Route_5" title="Chile Route 5">Route 5</a> (<a href="/wiki/Pan-American_Highway" title="Pan-American Highway">Pan-American Highway</a>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[219]</a></sup> These 4 countries are the ones with the best road infrastructure and with the largest number of double-lane highways.
</p><p>Due to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Andes_Mountains" title="Andes Mountains">Andes Mountains</a>, <a href="/wiki/Amazon_River" title="Amazon River">Amazon River</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Amazon_Forest" title="Amazon Forest">Amazon Forest</a>, there have always been difficulties in implementing transcontinental or bioceanic highways. Practically the only route that existed was the one that connected Brazil to Buenos Aires, in Argentina and later to Santiago, in Chile. However, in recent years, with the combined effort of countries, new routes have started to emerge, such as Brazil-Peru (<a href="/wiki/Interoceanic_Highway" title="Interoceanic Highway">Interoceanic Highway</a>), and a new highway between Brazil, Paraguay, northern Argentina and northern Chile (<a href="/wiki/Central_Bi-Oceanic_railway" title="Central Bi-Oceanic railway">Bioceanic Corridor</a>).
</p><p>There are more than 2,000 airports in Brazil. The country has the second largest number of airports in the world, behind only the United States. <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo/Guarulhos_International_Airport" title="São Paulo/Guarulhos International Airport">São Paulo International Airport</a>, located in the Metropolitan Region of São Paulo, is the largest and busiest in the country - the airport connects São Paulo to practically all major cities around the world. Brazil has 44 international airports, such as those in <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro/Gale%C3%A3o_International_Airport" title="Rio de Janeiro/Galeão International Airport">Rio de Janeiro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bras%C3%ADlia_International_Airport" title="Brasília International Airport">Brasília</a>, <a href="/wiki/Belo_Horizonte_International_Airport" title="Belo Horizonte International Airport">Belo Horizonte</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salgado_Filho_International_Airport" title="Salgado Filho International Airport">Porto Alegre</a>, <a href="/wiki/Herc%C3%ADlio_Luz_International_Airport" title="Hercílio Luz International Airport">Florianópolis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marechal_Rondon_International_Airport" title="Marechal Rondon International Airport">Cuiabá</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salvador_International_Airport" title="Salvador International Airport">Salvador</a>, <a href="/wiki/Recife/Guararapes%E2%80%93Gilberto_Freyre_International_Airport" title="Recife/Guararapes–Gilberto Freyre International Airport">Recife</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fortaleza_Airport" title="Fortaleza Airport">Fortaleza</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bel%C3%A9m/Val-de-Cans_International_Airport" title="Belém/Val-de-Cans International Airport">Belém</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eduardo_Gomes_International_Airport" title="Eduardo Gomes International Airport">Manaus</a>, among others. Argentina has important international airports such as <a href="/wiki/Ministro_Pistarini_International_Airport" title="Ministro Pistarini International Airport">Buenos Aires</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ingeniero_Aeron%C3%A1utico_Ambrosio_L.V._Taravella_International_Airport" title="Ingeniero Aeronáutico Ambrosio L.V. Taravella International Airport">Cordoba</a>, <a href="/wiki/San_Carlos_de_Bariloche_Airport" title="San Carlos de Bariloche Airport">Bariloche</a>, <a href="/wiki/Governor_Francisco_Gabrielli_International_Airport" title="Governor Francisco Gabrielli International Airport">Mendoza</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mart%C3%ADn_Miguel_de_G%C3%BCemes_International_Airport" title="Martín Miguel de Güemes International Airport">Salta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cataratas_del_Iguaz%C3%BA_International_Airport" title="Cataratas del Iguazú International Airport">Puerto Iguazú</a>, <a href="/wiki/Presidente_Per%C3%B3n_International_Airport" title="Presidente Perón International Airport">Neuquén</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ushuaia_%E2%80%93_Malvinas_Argentinas_International_Airport" title="Ushuaia – Malvinas Argentinas International Airport">Usuhaia</a>, among others. Chile has important international airports such as <a href="/wiki/Arturo_Merino_Ben%C3%ADtez_International_Airport" title="Arturo Merino Benítez International Airport">Santiago</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9s_Sabella_G%C3%A1lvez_International_Airport" title="Andrés Sabella Gálvez International Airport">Antofagasta</a>, <a href="/wiki/El_Tepual_Airport" title="El Tepual Airport">Puerto Montt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Presidente_Carlos_Ib%C3%A1%C3%B1ez_del_Campo_International_Airport" title="Presidente Carlos Ibáñez del Campo International Airport">Punta Arenas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Diego_Aracena_International_Airport" title="Diego Aracena International Airport">Iquique</a>, among others. Colombia has important international airports such as <a href="/wiki/El_Dorado_International_Airport" title="El Dorado International Airport">Bogotá</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Mar%C3%ADa_C%C3%B3rdova_International_Airport" title="José María Córdova International Airport">Medellín</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rafael_N%C3%BA%C3%B1ez_International_Airport" title="Rafael Núñez International Airport">Cartagena</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alfonso_Bonilla_Arag%C3%B3n_International_Airport" title="Alfonso Bonilla Aragón International Airport">Cali</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ernesto_Cortissoz_International_Airport" title="Ernesto Cortissoz International Airport">Barranquilla</a>, among others. Other important airports are those in the capitals of Uruguay (<a href="/wiki/Carrasco_International_Airport" title="Carrasco International Airport">Montevideo</a>), Paraguay (<a href="/wiki/Silvio_Pettirossi_International_Airport" title="Silvio Pettirossi International Airport">Asunción</a>), Peru (<a href="/wiki/Jorge_Ch%C3%A1vez_International_Airport" title="Jorge Chávez International Airport">Lima</a>), Bolivia (<a href="/wiki/El_Alto_International_Airport" title="El Alto International Airport">La Paz</a>) and Ecuador (<a href="/wiki/Mariscal_Sucre_International_Airport" title="Mariscal Sucre International Airport">Quito</a>).  The 10 busiest airports in South America in 2017 were: São Paulo-Guarulhos (Brazil), Bogotá (Colombia), São Paulo-Congonhas (Brazil), Santiago (Chile), Lima (Peru), Brasília (Brazil), Rio de Janeiro (Brazil), Buenos Aires-Aeroparque (Argentina), Buenos Aires-Ezeiza (Argentina), and Minas Gerais (Brazil).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[220]</a></sup>
</p><p>About ports, Brazil has some of the busiest ports in South America, such as <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Santos" title="Port of Santos">Port of Santos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Port of Rio de Janeiro">Port of Rio de Janeiro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Paranagu%C3%A1" title="Port of Paranaguá">Port of Paranaguá</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Itaja%C3%AD" title="Port of Itajaí">Port of Itajaí</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Rio_Grande" title="Port of Rio Grande">Port of Rio Grande</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_S%C3%A3o_Francisco_do_Sul" title="Port of São Francisco do Sul">Port of São Francisco do Sul</a> and <a href="/wiki/Suape_Port" title="Suape Port">Suape Port</a>. Argentina has ports such as <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Buenos_Aires" title="Port of Buenos Aires">Port of Buenos Aires</a> and <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Rosario" title="Port of Rosario">Port of Rosario</a>. Chile has important ports in <a href="/wiki/Valpara%C3%ADso" title="Valparaíso">Valparaíso</a>, <a href="/wiki/Caldera,_Chile" title="Caldera, Chile">Caldera</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mejillones" title="Mejillones">Mejillones</a>, <a href="/wiki/Antofagasta" title="Antofagasta">Antofagasta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iquique" title="Iquique">Iquique</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arica" title="Arica">Arica</a> and <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Montt" title="Puerto Montt">Puerto Montt</a>. Colombia has important ports such as <a href="/wiki/Buenaventura,_Valle_del_Cauca" title="Buenaventura, Valle del Cauca">Buenaventura</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cartagena_Container_Terminal" title="Cartagena Container Terminal">Cartagena Container Terminal</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Puerto_Bolivar,_Colombia" title="Puerto Bolivar, Colombia">Puerto Bolivar</a>. Peru has important ports in <a href="/wiki/Callao" title="Callao">Callao</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ilo,_Peru" title="Ilo, Peru">Ilo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Matarani" title="Matarani">Matarani</a>. The 15 busiest ports in South America are: Port of Santos (Brazil), Port of Bahia de Cartagena (Colombia), Callao (Peru), Guayaquil (Ecuador), Buenos Aires (Argentina), San Antonio (Chile), Buenaventura (Colombia), Itajaí (Brazil), Valparaíso (Chile), Montevideo (Uruguay), Paranaguá (Brazil), Rio Grande (Brazil), São Francisco do Sul (Brazil), Manaus (Brazil) and Coronel (Chile).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[221]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Brazilian railway network has an extension of about 30,000 kilometers. It's basically used for transporting ores.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234">[222]</a></sup> The Argentine rail network, with 47,000 km of tracks, was one of the largest in the world and continues to be the most extensive in Latin America. It came to have about 100,000 km of rails, but the lifting of tracks and the emphasis placed on motor transport gradually reduced it. It has four different trails and international connections with Paraguay, Bolivia, Chile, Brazil and Uruguay. Chile has almost 7,000 km of railways, with connections to Argentina, Bolivia and Peru. Colombia has only about 3,500 km of railways.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[223]</a></sup>
</p><p>Among the main Brazilian <a href="/wiki/Waterway" title="Waterway">waterways</a>, two stand out: <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Hidrovia_Tiet%C3%AA-Paran%C3%A1&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Hidrovia Tietê-Paraná (page does not exist)">Hidrovia Tietê-Paraná</a> (which has a length of 2,400 km, 1,600 on the Paraná River and 800 km on the Tietê River, draining agricultural production from the states of Mato Grosso, Mato Grosso do Sul, Goiás and part of Rondônia, Tocantins and Minas Gerais) and <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Hidrovia_do_Solim%C3%B5es-Amazonas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Hidrovia do Solimões-Amazonas (page does not exist)">Hidrovia do Solimões-Amazonas</a> (it has two sections: Solimões, which extends from Tabatinga to Manaus, with approximately 1600 km, and Amazonas, which extends from Manaus to Belém, with 1650 km. Almost entirely passenger transport from the Amazon plain is done by this waterway, in addition to practically all cargo transportation that is directed to the major regional centers of Belém and Manaus). In Brazil, this transport is still underutilized: the most important waterway stretches, from an economic point of view, are found in the Southeast and South of the country. Its full use still depends on the construction of locks, major dredging works and, mainly, of ports that allow intermodal integration. In <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a>, the waterway network is made up of the La Plata, Paraná, Paraguay and Uruguay rivers. The main river ports are <a href="/wiki/Z%C3%A1rate,_Buenos_Aires" title="Zárate, Buenos Aires">Zárate</a> and <a href="/wiki/Campana_Partido" title="Campana Partido">Campana</a>. The port of Buenos Aires is historically the first in individual importance, but the area known as Up-River, which stretches along 67 km of the Santa Fé portion of the Paraná River, brings together 17 ports that concentrate 50% of the total exports of the country.
</p><p>Only two railroads are continental: the Transandina, which connects <a href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires" title="Buenos Aires">Buenos Aires</a>, in Argentina to <a href="/wiki/Valpara%C3%ADso" title="Valparaíso">Valparaíso</a>, in Chile, and the Brazil–Bolivia Railroad, which makes it the connection between the port of <a href="/wiki/Santos,_S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="Santos, São Paulo">Santos</a> in Brazil and the city of <a href="/wiki/Santa_Cruz_de_la_Sierra" title="Santa Cruz de la Sierra">Santa Cruz de la Sierra</a>, in Bolivia. In addition, there is the <a href="/wiki/Pan-American_Highway" title="Pan-American Highway">Pan-American Highway</a>, which crosses Argentina and the Andean countries from north to south, although some stretches are unfinished.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[224]</a></sup>
</p><p>Two areas of greater density occur in the railway sector: the platinum network, which develops around the <a href="/wiki/R%C3%ADo_de_la_Plata_Basin" title="Río de la Plata Basin">Platine region</a>, largely belonging to Argentina, with more than 45,000 km in length; And the <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Region,_Brazil" title="Southeast Region, Brazil">Southeast Brazil</a> network, which mainly serves the <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_(state)" title="São Paulo (state)">state of São Paulo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro_(state)" title="Rio de Janeiro (state)">state of Rio de Janeiro</a> and <a href="/wiki/Minas_Gerais" title="Minas Gerais">Minas Gerais</a>. Brazil and Argentina also stand out in the road sector. In addition to the modern roads that extend through northern Argentina and south-east and south of Brazil, a vast road complex aims to link <a href="/wiki/Bras%C3%ADlia" title="Brasília">Brasília</a>, the federal capital, to the South, Southeast, Northeast and Northern regions of Brazil.
</p><p>South America has one of the largest bays of navigable inland waterways in the world, represented mainly by the <a href="/wiki/Amazon_basin" title="Amazon basin">Amazon basin</a>, the <a href="/wiki/R%C3%ADo_de_la_Plata_Basin" title="Río de la Plata Basin">Platine basin</a>, the São Francisco and the Orinoco basins, Brazil having about 54,000 km navigable, while Argentina has 6,500 km and Venezuela, 1,200 km.
</p><p>The two main merchant fleets also belong to Brazil and Argentina. The following are those of Chile, Venezuela, Peru and Colombia. The largest ports in commercial movement are those of <a href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires" title="Buenos Aires">Buenos Aires</a>, <a href="/wiki/Santos,_S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="Santos, São Paulo">Santos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%ADa_Blanca" title="Bahía Blanca">Bahía Blanca</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rosario,_Santa_Fe" title="Rosario, Santa Fe">Rosario</a>, <a href="/wiki/Valpara%C3%ADso" title="Valparaíso">Valparaíso</a>, <a href="/wiki/Recife" title="Recife">Recife</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salvador,_Bahia" title="Salvador, Bahia">Salvador</a>, <a href="/wiki/Montevideo" title="Montevideo">Montevideo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paranagu%C3%A1" title="Paranaguá">Paranaguá</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rio_Grande,_Rio_Grande_do_Sul" title="Rio Grande, Rio Grande do Sul">Rio Grande</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fortaleza" title="Fortaleza">Fortaleza</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bel%C3%A9m" title="Belém">Belém</a> and <a href="/wiki/Maracaibo" title="Maracaibo">Maracaibo</a>.
</p><p>In South America, <a href="/wiki/Commercial_aviation" title="Commercial aviation">commercial aviation</a> has a magnificent expansion field, which has one of the largest traffic density lines in the world, Rio de Janeiro–São Paulo, and large airports, such as <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo%E2%80%93Congonhas_Airport" title="São Paulo–Congonhas Airport">Congonhas</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo%E2%80%93Guarulhos_International_Airport" title="São Paulo–Guarulhos International Airport">São Paulo–Guarulhos International</a> and <a href="/wiki/Viracopos_International_Airport" title="Viracopos International Airport">Viracopos</a> (São Paulo), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro%E2%80%93Gale%C3%A3o_International_Airport" title="Rio de Janeiro–Galeão International Airport">Rio de Janeiro International</a> and <a href="/wiki/Santos_Dumont_Airport" title="Santos Dumont Airport">Santos Dumont</a> (Rio de Janeiro), <a href="/wiki/El_Dorado_International_Airport" title="El Dorado International Airport">El Dorado</a> (Bogotá), <a href="/wiki/Ministro_Pistarini_International_Airport" title="Ministro Pistarini International Airport">Ezeiza</a> (Buenos Aires), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tancredo_Neves_International_Airport" title="Tancredo Neves International Airport">Tancredo Neves International Airport</a> (Belo Horizonte), <a href="/wiki/Afonso_Pena_International_Airport" title="Afonso Pena International Airport">Curitiba International Airport</a> (Curitiba), Brasilia, Caracas, Montevideo, Lima, <a href="/wiki/Viru_Viru_International_Airport" title="Viru Viru International Airport">Viru Viru International Airport</a> (Santa Cruz de la Sierra), Recife, Salvador, Salgado Filho International Airport (Porto Alegre), Fortaleza, Manaus and Belém.
</p><p>The main public transport in major cities is the bus. Many cities also have a diverse system of metro and subway trains, the first of which was the <a href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires_Underground" title="Buenos Aires Underground">Buenos Aires subte</a>, opened 1913.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[225]</a></sup>  The <a href="/wiki/Santiago_Metro" title="Santiago Metro">Santiago subway</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Home_238-0"><a href="#cite_note-Home-238">[226]</a></sup> is the largest network in South America, with 103 km, while the <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_Metro" title="São Paulo Metro">São Paulo subway</a> is the largest in transportation, with more than 4.6 million passengers per day<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2014ridership_239-0"><a href="#cite_note-2014ridership-239">[227]</a></sup> and was voted the best in the Americas. <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a> installed the first railroad of the continent in 1854. Today the city has a vast and diversified system of metropolitan trains, integrated with buses and subway. Recently it was also inaugurated in the city a Light Rail System called <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro_Light_Rail" title="Rio de Janeiro Light Rail">VLT</a>, a small electrical trams at low speed, while <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="São Paulo">São Paulo</a> inaugurated its <a href="/wiki/Line_15_(S%C3%A3o_Paulo_Metro)" title="Line 15 (São Paulo Metro)">monorail</a>, the first of South America.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2017)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> In Brazil, an express bus system called Bus Rapid Transit (BRT), which operates in several cities, has also been developed. <a href="/wiki/Mi_Telef%C3%A9rico" title="Mi Teleférico">Mi Teleférico</a>, also known as Teleférico <a href="/wiki/La_Paz" title="La Paz">La Paz</a>–<a href="/wiki/El_Alto" title="El Alto">El Alto</a> (La Paz–El Alto Cable Car), is an aerial cable car urban transit system serving the La Paz–El Alto metropolitan area in Bolivia.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=South_America&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: See also">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1093669538">.mw-parser-output .portalbox{padding:0}.mw-parser-output .portalborder{border:solid #aaa 1px}.mw-parser-output .portalbox.tleft{margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0}.mw-parser-output .portalbox.tright{margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul{display:table;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:175px;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .portalborder>ul{padding:0.1em;background:#f9f9f9}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li{display:table-row}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li>span:first-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li>span:last-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle}</style><div aria-label="Portals" class="noprint plainlist portalbox portalborder tright" role="navigation">
<ul>
<li><span><img alt="map" class="noviewer" data-file-height="541" data-file-width="541" decoding="async" height="28" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/South_America_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/28px-South_America_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/South_America_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/42px-South_America_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/South_America_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/56px-South_America_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 2x" width="28"/></span><span><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Portal:South_America" title="Portal:South America">South America portal</a></span></li>
<li><span><img alt="icon" class="noviewer" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="600" decoding="async" height="28" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Terra.png/28px-Terra.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Terra.png/42px-Terra.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Terra.png/56px-Terra.png 2x" width="28"/></span><span><a href="/wiki/Portal:Geography" title="Portal:Geography">Geography portal</a></span></li></ul></div>
